summary:
Here's a summary of my experience with depression, from my perspective:

"I haven't been officially diagnosed with depression, but I strongly suspect I might be depressed. A lot of this started about five years ago, right after my mom passed away. It's been really rough since then. On a daily basis, there are so many things that make me think about her – driving by a restaurant she liked, watching certain TV shows, just anything can trigger a memory. I felt down about it just yesterday.

Beyond that, the job situation here in California isn't stable, and that definitely adds to how I'm feeling. I've noticed some changes in my behavior; I've become more reserved and tend to keep to myself a lot. I don't really have disturbing thoughts, but I do feel a lot of things. Even when I get a good night's sleep, which is usually pretty easy for me, I wake up feeling grumpy, irritable, fidgety, like a big ball of nerves.

When I do feel down because of memories of my mom, my main way of coping is to think about the good times. I try not to stay in that sad place for too long; I just think about it and then try to move on. Despite these feelings, I have a very close family – we're intertwined, sometimes too close! And I have great friends who've been with me since high school. My big sister Michelle and my friend Troy are always in my corner, no matter what. In fact, I was really happy just yesterday celebrating my birthday with family and friends, cooking, listening to music, and talking about the old days when my mom was still here and we were all one unit. It was a really nice evening."

summary:
When asked if I've been diagnosed with depression, my answer is no. I haven't been told I have depression.

However, I definitely make a conscious effort to manage my mood. I try to stay happy because, for me, I'd much rather be happy than sad. My kids are a huge source of that happiness; they really keep me going and sane. Just seeing them run up to me from school, happy and excited, truly makes my day. My family in general has been a very positive influence in my life.

Life certainly has its challenges, though. Being a single parent is inherently difficult, and my job as a bus operator is very stressful. I've also experienced a lot of deaths around me, which is just part of life. Currently, I'm dealing with a lot of frustration regarding my oldest daughter's situation. It's tough because it feels like I'm talking to a wall when I try to give her advice, and it's frustrating when she doesn't seem to hear me.

Sleep is something I really have to prioritize. I have my days when it comes to getting a good night's rest, but I know how important it is, especially with my demanding job. When I don't sleep well, I definitely feel it – I become irritated, tired, and lazy, and all I want to do is lay down and get the rest I need.

Despite these things, I consider myself a go-getter. I'm dependable and responsible, and I'm actively working to move up at Metro, even starting supervisory classes next week. I believe in learning from my mistakes and always striving to better myself, even if it means going back to school later in life. To relax and manage stress, I like to read, take long walks, have a hot bath, or simply close my eyes and meditate. At work, I've learned to remain calm and professional no matter the circumstances, which helps me handle the daily pressures. I consider myself a people person and generally get along well with others. Ultimately, I just keep pushing forward, with my kids as my main motivation.

summary:
I've been dealing with depression for a long time, really, I've always felt this way in my life, though I was formally diagnosed about three or four years ago. It's pretty depressing right now; it's hard, it sucks. My mood is just not right; I'm always feeling down and depressed.

This impacts everything. Getting a good night's sleep is really difficult; I couldn't sleep last night because I was just thinking about my situation, like the car payment that was due. Sometimes I just want to sleep a lot, but then other times I can't. My energy is low, and I've lost interest in things. My appetite is also all over the place – either I have no appetite or I'm eating too much and the wrong things.

A huge part of my current struggle is not being able to find a job. I've applied everywhere, from entry-level to management, but I just can't get anything that pays, and it's getting really hard. This financial strain means I'm not in a position to travel, and I'm just trying to survive day by day, trying to see if I can eat. Things got even tougher recently; my sister passed away six months ago, and then two weeks ago, I became homeless and jobless. There was a point where I just missed her so much I wanted to be with her, and I'd like to give up. But I can't, my parents just buried their daughter, and they don't need to bury another one. This isn't the first time I've felt this way; 20 years ago, after being a corporate manager for two decades, I even tried to commit suicide instead of going back to work. It's been rough trying to pick up the pieces since then.

I used to be an extrovert, but now I'm quite an introvert and I stay to myself. I don't feel as confident, charming, or social anymore, which makes me isolate. My family is pretty dysfunctional, and I can't really depend on them, so I just depend on myself. I'd love to talk to someone, but I don't have health insurance, so therapy isn't an option for me right now, even though it was useful in the past.

To cope, I meditate, which helps me relax. I also love to skateboard, and sometimes I'll just go for a nice sunset skate to relax and meditate on my board. Staying active outdoors helps too.

I was feeling a bit happy a couple of days ago because I was getting callbacks and things were looking up, but time isn't on my side financially. I don't have what it takes to stay in LA for two more weeks to connect the dots, so my car is packed, and I'm leaving.

summary:
Right now, I'm not doing very good. My wife just left about three weeks ago, and honestly, it's probably the hardest thing I've ever had to go through. It's really hit me hard; I haven't been able to sleep since she left.

I've been diagnosed with a type of depression that tends to last for months on end. I went to therapy a few years ago, about three or four, and that's when I got that diagnosis after some cognitive and memory tests.

My mood is really unstable. I can feel really happy one second, and then it just goes away, and I'm really sad again, usually because I start thinking about things. It's like I constantly have to try and keep my mind off stuff, to move forward, but it's hard to explain – it's just something you feel.

Looking back, I really regret how I handled things, especially with my wife. I was often angry, and I'd break stuff; I even argued with my mom on the way over here. I was basically blocking out the external universe, just focusing on myself and other things to escape real life. I wasn't paying attention to her, and that, along with my anger, contributed to her leaving. If I could go back, I'd tell myself not to mess up and let myself get so depressed about things that drove her away.

To cope, I just try to bury my head in stuff, do whatever I can to keep my mind off everything. I do yoga and play video games, just anything to escape and not focus on what's really happening.

summary:
Here's a summary of my experience with depression, in my own words:

While I'm feeling pretty good lately and my depression and anxiety are currently under control, it's something I've dealt with for a long time. I was diagnosed with "minor depression" about five or six years ago, but truthfully, I've had it off and on all my life. It's often been more anxiety than depression for me, and I first started experiencing that anxiety as a teenager. I understand that depression can sometimes go hand-in-hand with anxiety if it's not managed.

I don't really have specific triggers for my anxiety; I think of it more as "free-floating" or an "organic reason," perhaps a chemical imbalance in my brain.

One of the consistent challenges I've faced, pretty much my whole life, is getting a good night's sleep. It's just not easy for me. I almost always wake up at least once in the middle of the night, usually to go to the bathroom. Sometimes, if I wake up really early, I just can't fall back asleep. In those cases, I'll get up and do some work on the computer before trying to go back to bed later. My sleep patterns are definitely influenced by my schedule and what the kids need.

When I'm not sleeping well, I might complain a bit about being tired or having body aches, but overall, I think I manage. My kids are aware when I'm tired, and they're usually very helpful; my older daughter might pitch in more, or another daughter might even try to cook dinner.

I've found therapy to be incredibly useful. I've seen its benefits firsthand, especially through my daughter's experience with anxiety. My husband and I have been attending a DBT group with her, and it's been very informative and helpful, teaching strategies for living in the moment and managing one's mind.

I'm fortunate to have strong support systems. My church and my faith are incredibly important to me. My husband is also a great gift in my life; he's very logical and grounded, and we balance each other out when one of us gets emotional or upset. My family, including my children, also provides a lot of support.

Despite these challenges, I also experience a lot of joy. Recently, renewing my marriage vows in Israel was a truly moving and beautiful experience. I also find happiness in family gatherings, like Christmas and my dad's birthday. I've also gained a lot of wisdom with age; I don't worry about what people think of me anymore, which is a freedom I truly appreciate now.

summary:
While I haven't been diagnosed with depression, and I generally consider myself to be in a good mood every day – waking up usually puts me there, and a good meal helps too – there are some areas where I face challenges that impact my daily life.

Lately, getting a good night's sleep has been pretty tough. I think it's my own fault because I've been staying up so late, almost like I'm turning into a night owl all of a sudden. When I don't sleep well, I feel sluggish and tired all day, and I just end up laying around. This has been a recent change for me.

I definitely consider myself an introvert; I'm all about myself, and I feel that way more times than not. When I get upset or feel like people are trying to lie to me or think I'm dumber than I am, I try to get away from everything and go into my own space. Despite that, I'm actually really good at controlling my temper.

Overall, I'm pretty close to my family, and my parents have been a big positive influence on my life. I had a really fun New Year's Eve party recently with tons of friends, which was a great time. I see myself as open-minded, kind, and generally an even-keeled guy.

summary:
Here's a summary of my experience with depression, from my perspective:

About a year ago, I started to recognize that something was wrong with me; I just wasn't myself. For about a year and a half now, I've been feeling this way. I'm always tired and lethargic, often just laying around, and I'm not excited about things anymore. I find myself feeling a bit irritable and cranky. It's a general sense of not feeling like myself.

A lot has been going on in my life, and I've lost a lot. I recently lost my dad, who was my last parent, and that's been really hard. I'm also currently unemployed, and I don't have the funds or the health to travel like I used to. I worry a lot, especially about my children, even though they're adults now. I'm not around them as much, and I certainly worry about them.

To cope, I try to remove myself from situations that annoy me, or I just walk away to control my emotions. Sometimes I just watch TV. I also see a psychologist, and we talk about things. I find it helpful, though I don't want to go into detail. I still enjoy sports, like playing soccer or watching USC football, especially when my team wins; that usually puts me in a good mood.

I have many regrets, too many to name, but I am very proud of my children. My mother, who passed away ten years ago, was a huge positive influence throughout my entire life, even though she's no longer here. I guess I've just been dealing with a lot of stuff.

summary:
Here is a summary of my experience with depression, in my own words:

About one to two years ago, I was diagnosed with depression. Before that, I had been feeling really down and had lost interest in things I normally enjoyed. I became sort of withdrawn and found it very difficult to focus on my tasks. I also noticed that I had lost my appetite and wasn't sleeping well. I struggled with concentrating and focusing, which led to me not getting my assignments done on time. These issues were what prompted me to seek help from a doctor.

Lately, I've been feeling good. When I was diagnosed, I decided I didn't want to take medication for it and instead looked for other ways to manage the problem. I was influenced by some friends who were doing meditation, so I started doing yoga and meditation myself about a year ago. That has helped a lot.

Getting rid of depression is still a little difficult. While I've generally been able to sleep within half an hour, there are still days when it takes me almost one or two hours to fall asleep. Even when I do sleep, I wouldn't say that sleeping alone makes me feel better.

As the interviewee, I can tell you that my experience with depression is essentially non-existent. I haven't been diagnosed with any mental health conditions like PTSD, and I don't find myself struggling with the typical symptoms of depression.

My mood and emotional state are generally very positive. I'm quite relaxed and don't tend to take things too seriously. I love the holidays, especially Christmas, and I felt absolutely fantastic during the recent season, enjoying all the preparations, baking, and experimenting with new recipes. I find a lot of happiness in my family, particularly my children, and I'm very proud of the people they've become. I enjoy being social, playing bridge and chess, and traveling. My best friend would describe me as level-headed with a great sense of humor.

In terms of my daily functioning, I have no problem getting a good night's sleep; it's usually very, very easy for me. The only time my sleep is affected is if I'm feeling a bit anxious about upcoming deadlines or projects. I don't like to be late or make mistakes, so I might stay up all night to ensure everything is perfect. This anxiety is situational, though, and not a constant state.

When it comes to coping, I don't really get annoyed much. If I can't straighten out a problem, I just let it go. I don't like confrontation and tend to avoid arguments. Overall, I feel very good and content with my life.

summary:
Here's a summary of my experience with depression, in my own words:

"Overall, I'd say I'm doing fine today. I really love living in LA – the beach, the weather, everything. My family is number one for me, especially my mother; she's a very good-hearted person and gives me good advice. For fun, I like to go to the gym, exercise, go to the beach, party every once in a while, watch basketball and football, and take trips, like to Vegas. I was just at the gym last night, actually. Taking a trip helps me get away from the city for a minute, though I'm a city boy, so it can't be too long. Going to the beach also helps me relax.

However, controlling my temper has been a real problem for me over the years. I guess you could say I have a little anger management problem. I had a problem with someone just yesterday, though I forget what it was about. Sometimes, people just get on my nerves; the way they are, I guess. When I'm feeling angry, I usually go to the gym to work it out.

Lately, I feel like I'm not going forward as fast as I want to. It's kind of hard, but it is what it is. I've accomplished some big goals, like getting my GED two years ago and finally getting my dream job at LAX, which I'm really proud of. But I just want to accomplish more, and it's taking longer than I thought it would.

I also experience a lot of mood swings. They happen all the time – yesterday, maybe even today. It could be just something small, and I'll just snap and get angry. It's really hard to control my anger, especially when I'm going through a few things in my life that aren't very pleasant. Honestly, I don't think I'm going to be able to control it.

My best friends describe me as a character, very outgoing, and with a good sense of humor. They understand when I'm going through something or when I get mad about something easily, but they also know I can just laugh right after. They see me as smart, intelligent, and strong.

Looking back, when I was a teenager, around 14 or 15, I was very restless and destructive. I went to a rehab or placement after doing a little bit of time, but I AWOLed, I escaped, and then I went back to jail. That's when it stopped. If I could give my younger self advice, it would be to stay in school and not join a gang, and definitely to control those anger issues I had back then."

summary:
Okay, so, I'm Ellie, and I've been dealing with depression for a long time now. I was actually diagnosed when I was pretty young, around 15, so that's about 17 years ago. My parents were the ones who really pushed for me to get help back then, even though initially they thought it might be ADHD.

Lately, I've been feeling a bit more down than usual. A big part of it is that I just graduated, and my whole routine of being in school 24/7 has ended. Without that structure, it's been really weird trying to figure out what to do with my time and how to stay productive. It's also been pretty depressing realizing that my good grades and intelligence in school don't necessarily translate to real-world job skills, especially since there aren't many marine biology jobs here in California.

My mood can be really volatile. When I'm feeling really bad, it's like that scene from Fight Club – I become a complete panicked, anxious wreck. I lose my ability to deal with things, I'm much more likely to lose my temper, and I just can't regulate my moods. It's easier for me to pinpoint when I feel really, really bad than when I feel truly happy. The last time I felt really happy was about 10 days ago, on New Year's Eve/Day, when I was with my boyfriend and friends on a trip. Before that, it was a few months ago on a trip, but I think I might have forgotten my medicine, which then impacted my sleep and spiraled things.

Sleep is a huge struggle for me; it's almost impossible to get a good night's sleep. I've had trouble falling asleep since I was a little kid, but about four years ago, it got really severe. I just couldn't sleep through the night, only getting about four hours, sometimes waking up every hour. I'd wake up feeling like a complete wreck. For the past four years, I've had to take Trazodone just to be able to sleep.

As for coping, I try to meditate, exercise, and get out in nature to relax. I also make an effort to unplug from my computer, technology, and people sometimes, as social encounters tend to be draining for me, even though I consider myself a social introvert. When I'm annoyed, I tend to rant to my boyfriend.

I haven't been in regular therapy for about three years because I wasn't enjoying the relationship with my last therapist, but I still see a psychiatrist for my med checks. I do believe therapy can be really useful, but only if you have the right therapist; a bad relationship can be incredibly harmful. My boyfriend is a big support for me; he's kind of my default best friend and is very supportive, though he often tells me I'm too hard on myself.

summary:
Here's a summary of my experience, in my own words:

When you ask if everything is very well, I have to say, "No." It's not. I don't really feel "down" in the way some people might describe it, but when I'm "off the ground," I guess I can get agitated. It's a feeling I can't quite pinpoint.

It's hard for me to think of the last time I felt "really happy." Maybe when I was flying a private plane, that was cool. But honestly, I don't think there's any reason to get "super happy." I tend to stay pretty level, pretty even-minded, even-kill. I just stay pretty level, you know?

To manage things, I focus on what makes me feel good. Playing my guitar is a big one – I love playing chords and songs, and playing with other musicians at a rehearsal studio is awesome. I also make sure to go to the gym; I was there last night. And I really enjoy flying planes. These things help me stay on an even keel.

My parents have always been a positive influence, strong people, and I'm close with my family. I'm proud of my achievements, like racing motocross and being one of the first Black professionals in that sport. Even with all that, there's just a general sense that things aren't "very well," and I don't really experience those intense highs of happiness.

summary:
My experience with depression really started about two years and two months ago. A significant trigger for me was realizing I didn't have any family members left in the United States, which led to a profound sense of loneliness and depression.

For a while, I didn't want to admit how I was feeling, but after being depressed for so long, I knew I had to do something. That's when I decided to seek help. I started with a counselor and then moved on to group therapy. Therapy has affected me a lot; it's truly helped me cope with things, and it's nice to have someone to talk to. I particularly enjoy group therapy because sitting with others and talking about our likes, dislikes, and problems often reveals that someone else is going through the same thing. We can share our experiences and what helps make things better. I'm still going to therapy now, and lately, I've noticed I'm getting more positive and feeling better.

Even though I'm feeling better overall, sleep is still a challenge for me. It's about 50-50; some nights I sleep well, and some nights I don't. When I get two nights in a row of no sleep, it's really hard, and it definitely leads to a lack of energy the next day.

In my daily life, I'm generally a bit shy and tend to stay to myself a lot. I work part-time and I'm currently going back to school. To help my mood, I make sure to do things I enjoy, like walking along the beach or bike riding. The beach, especially, is very relaxing for me. I've also been working on managing my anger. I try not to get angry, but sometimes I do, especially when people provoke me. I'm learning to walk away from things, and I'd say I'm getting better, about 75% under control.

I recently felt really happy during the holidays a couple of weeks ago. Christmas trees and spending time with kids always make me feel good. I'm very proud of having been married and raising my two daughters. They're grown now, which makes things easier, though I still worry about them, especially given a past family experience. I also had a difficult argument with one of my daughters recently about finances, which was really hard because I don't like arguing with my children. Despite these challenges, I'm committed to staying positive and continuing to work on myself.

summary:
Here’s how I’d describe my experience with depression:

Right now, I'm feeling really, extremely depressed. A big part of it is just being so tired; I sleep a lot longer than I used to. I’ve lost that drive and motivation I had before. It's like I just have to try to be strong and get through it, you know?

This depression impacts my daily life quite a bit. I used to keep a perfect house, and I was the perfect wife, but not anymore, especially now that I’m divorced. When I’m depressed like this, I’m afraid I’ll just stay home and lay in bed all day, or just play Farmville. I could literally farm for eight hours straight on Farmville if I let myself.

I think poverty is a big factor in how I’m feeling. My divorce also played a role, though it wasn’t me, it was him and his drugs.

Back in 1984, when I was 19, I had major anxiety and couldn’t sleep, so I saw a psychiatrist. I think talking to someone, especially a neutral professional, is really good. It gives you a chance to talk and hopefully get some answers.

To cope, I just try to be strong. Having something to do, a goal, somewhere to go – like today’s interview, for instance – actually puts me in a good mood. Otherwise, I’d probably just stay home. I also rely on my daily Starbucks and Orange Gina, and unfortunately, cigarettes, because I’m addicted. Eating something good and healthy at night helps too. I have a lot of regrets, but I try not to dwell on them because there’s nothing I can do about the past.

Overall, I’m an open book. I know I’m good at a lot of things – I’m a good hairdresser, makeup artist, I crochet, knit, and make jewelry. But this depression makes it hard to maintain the 'perfect' life I used to have.

summary:
I've definitely experienced depression in my life. While I've been feeling pretty good for the most part recently, there are times when I feel a little blue. Often, these low moods are triggered if I let regrets come into my mind, especially about missed opportunities, like when I first got to Los Angeles and didn't pursue becoming a GRIP, or financial decisions that might have led to a different life. Financial concerns, in general, can really bring me down.

One of the biggest challenges I face, particularly with my goal of becoming a screenwriter, is that it's hard for me to always maintain focus and motivation. I tend to let other things distract me.

In terms of daily life, I'm fortunate that I don't usually have problems sleeping. If I don't sleep well, though, I can become grumpy, tired, and irritable. My best friend might even say they'd like to see me more accomplished in my goals and maybe a little happier. While I can be introverted, especially when I'm writing and need to spend time alone, I'm also friendly and outgoing when I'm not in that space. People often describe me as engaging.

When I do feel down, I've developed ways to cope. I can usually get out of it pretty quickly. Talking to someone has helped me in the past when I sought help for depression. Now, I rely on a range of strategies: I love listening to music, and watching movies is a great way to relax and take my mind off things. I meditate every day, which has been really beneficial – I don't get annoyed as easily as I used to. Taking walks in nature, especially by the ocean, is always calming. Recently, I've also learned a form of self-hypnosis to calm myself down, which I find very helpful, especially when I get angry or lose my temper. Looking forward to things like going to a movie, bowling, or just hanging out with people helps put me in a good mood. Feeling productive at work also contributes to my well-being. I believe it's important to say 'yes' to opportunities and be confident in what you want to achieve, no matter how you feel.

summary:
Here's a summary of my experience with depression, in my own words:

I haven't actually been diagnosed with depression, mostly because I haven't gone to a doctor about it – I just don't want to know. But I do recognize that there have been times in my life when I've been severely depressed. Usually, these are tied to specific circumstances, and my preference is to pull myself out of it before resorting to treatment.

A major period of deep depression hit me after my mother died. We had been in a long, year-long battle that we ultimately lost. Logically, I knew I wasn't to blame for her death, but it was incredibly hard to convince myself of that. I carried a lot of guilt and regret, especially because I neglected my own health during that last year of her life. I didn't eat right, didn't take my insulin properly, and ended up making myself very sick, even developing pulmonary embolisms in both lungs. I was 30, thinking I could just get over anything, but that wasn't true.

Her death felt like the rug was pulled out from under me; my whole world just fell apart. So much of my life had been based on being "my mother's daughter," and suddenly, that identity was gone. I just didn't want anything anymore. I became very distant from my husband, pushing everything away, and we almost got divorced because of it. There were times when I literally couldn't get up, I just wanted to stay in bed and sleep all day. I even thought about just curling up and dying.

What eventually pulled me out of that deep hole was the responsibility I felt for my cats. They don't have a choice about getting their own food or supplies. I realized I had to get up and provide for them. If it were just me, I honestly think I could live in my car and not care, as long as I was doing what I wanted with my life. But I have a family now, and that responsibility forces me to go out and face things, even when I don't want to. It's been a fight to get my health back and to get out of that depression, but having someone to take care of has been a strong motivating factor.

Right now, I often feel very anxious and nervous. My mind gets caught in a lot of "what ifs" – what if I can't find enough work, what if I can't maintain stability? I know it's pointless to worry about things that haven't happened, but the anxiety still creeps in. My way of dealing with this internal anxiety is to get things done, to figure things out, and make a solid plan. I know it's a cycle: I'll be really anxious, then I'll break things down to the fundamental issues, and the anxiety will lessen, only for something else to pop up and restart the cycle.

When it comes to happiness, I honestly can't recall the last time I felt "over joyously happy." That question actually stumped me. I do feel happy sometimes, and sometimes not so much; it's often just kind of in the middle. I guess I have what I'd call a "realistic, downer temperament."

I still carry a huge regret about not taking better care of myself during my mother's last year, wondering if my clouded judgment led to her health catastrophe. I know I'm hard on myself, but it stems from my deep desire to take responsibility for everyone and everything I care about. It's a struggle to separate my own ideals from what others want for themselves. But ultimately, I'm proud that despite the sacrifices, I'm fundamentally doing what I want with my life, which is more than many people can say.

summary:
Here is a summary of my experience with depression:

I'd say I'm a little depressed, though I believe everyone carries a bit of sadness at some point. For a long time, I've struggled with being angry and upset about things I can't control. I often tell myself to relax and not be so hard on myself. Even as a child, I felt different; things always seemed to affect me in a way that was unique compared to other kids.

In terms of my daily life, I'm generally quiet and introverted. While I enjoy outdoor activities, I mostly prefer to do them by myself. When faced with disrespect or conflict, I tend to shut down and reevaluate myself, focusing on how I come across to others, as I can't change anyone else. I usually just walk away from arguments because they don't resolve anything.

Socially, I'm aware that "no one wants to be around a depressed person," so when I'm with my best friend, I really try to be happy and present a positive situation for both of us. Happiness comes and goes for me, but I was genuinely happy today after seeing my best friend for the first time in a while.

My biggest regret in life was losing my mother. She was extremely close to me and truly shaped me into the person I am. Her passing was a profound loss.

When it comes to coping, I've always been someone who tries to handle my own problems and situations. I feel strongly that I should be able to control things myself as an individual. While I know seeking help is beneficial for others, like the PTSD veterans I've worked with, I don't feel it's for me. I've always been alone in dealing with my issues. Recently, I've started an exercise program, which is a new step in looking to myself for solutions. I believe that if I'm ever going to truly understand myself, I have to do the work on my own. Simple things like riding my bike, going for a walk, or exercising help me.

summary:
Here's a summary of my experience with depression, as if I were speaking:

My best friend would tell you that I can be depressed sometimes, though generally, I'm a good person. When I'm alone, I tend to be very "inter-minded," meaning I have a lot of thoughts that I keep to myself. In those moments, I don't really interact with people, though I can shift modes and be social when I need to.

My sleep is often affected; I might wake up in the middle of the night, especially if I'm planning things or overthinking. When I don't get enough sleep, I become very irritable. Lately, I've also felt anxious, particularly when I was searching for a stable place to live, as that process took a long time and caused a lot of stress.

I was diagnosed with PTSD about a year and a half ago. Before that, I just knew I'd often think about past situations and blamed them for my future. I used to try to avoid certain types of individuals or settings because they reminded me of when things happened that changed my future plans.

To cope, I've recently started doing yoga, which helps me relax. When I'm annoyed, I try to remain quiet, listen, and think of alternative ways to make the situation better. Therapy has been really helpful for me. At first, it was difficult to be open about my internal emotions, but now it's good because speaking about my issues relieves the tension of holding them inside. It's helped me worry less, and often, by talking things through, I can come up with better plans just by hearing myself speak. I also find that being around positive people, listening to music, watching comedy shows, and enjoying good food can really put me in a good mood. I'm living with my sister right now, and she makes it as comfortable as possible.

summary:
I've experienced periods where I felt really down, especially related to my son's disability. I used to feel guilty, sad, and even depressed about it, struggling with not knowing how to help him. It's truly very hard, and I don't sugarcoat that at all.

Currently, I can be quite moody, irritable, and short-tempered. I also find myself a bit more sensitive than usual. A lot of things frustrate me, like my mother's intrusive behavior and her strong opinions about me socializing. She believes that because I'm married with children, I should stay home almost all the time, and she's even put me down for wanting to go out with ex-coworkers. It's frustrating because I love my mom and hate feeling this way towards her, but sometimes she just doesn't understand that I'm an adult who needs to make my own decisions.

In terms of daily life, I'm generally doing okay, though I often feel a little tired. My sleep schedule is quite early; I go to bed around 8 or 8:30 PM and wake up around 1 or 1:30 AM, but I do get a good night's sleep if I stick to that. Socially, I do want to go out and connect with people, but my mother's expectations create a barrier.

I've been working on coping strategies. When I get frustrated, I might take a walk or try not to dwell on things. More recently, I'm actively trying to think more positively, especially about my son's disability. Instead of feeling sorry for him or myself, I'm focusing on finding more avenues and resources to help him. This shift has been really important for me. I also recently felt a great sense of happiness and accomplishment when I did well in school, getting A's and B's, especially since it had been a long time since I was in school. That really showed me, "wow, I can do this."

summary:
I was diagnosed with depression about a year ago. What got me to that point was just not feeling well; I couldn't pull myself out of it, and I just didn't feel right. My symptoms included feeling sad, having a general lack of energy, and not feeling motivated. I just wasn't my happy self.

Lately, I've been feeling tired, sad, depressed, and blue. I'm just not happy and I don't feel good. This has really impacted my daily life. I tend to stay to myself and don't go out with friends as much as I used to. It's been very hard. Sleep is also a big struggle for me; I don't sleep well at all. When I don't sleep, I feel crazy and distracted, and it makes it hard for me to cope with things – even easy, mundane tasks become difficult.

I've been in therapy since my diagnosis, and I still go. While I haven't noticed many changes in how I feel, and I still don't feel great, it is good to talk to someone and get things off my chest.

My mood can also be affected by external factors. I don't like cold weather, and I'm not comfortable in it at all, so whenever the weather changes, I tend to get down. Also, recently, I felt really happy about a month or so ago because of a new boyfriend, but now things are just "okay," and I guess the newness wore off, which has contributed to my current feelings.

Despite these challenges, being around my kids is always fun and puts me in a good mood. Recently, going out for Hawaiian food with my son, daughter-in-law, and daughter, and getting together with them at my house for Christmas, were things I really enjoyed. My kids are a great source of joy for me.

summary:
Here's a summary of my experience with depression, in my own words:

I was officially diagnosed with depression last October, though I truly believe I've been struggling with it for much longer than that. It was actually my doctors who noticed it while I was being treated for other medical issues.

My emotional state has shifted dramatically. I've never been suicidal, but I often have thought that I don't have much reason to live. I used to think I had a purpose, but now I feel like I've lost myself. I don't really have anyone in my life who I think cares enough about me, even if I were gone. I used to feel like I was enough, that I had purpose, but I've lost quite a bit of that sense of self. I find myself overwhelmed and preoccupied, just trying to stay alive and on top of things. I don't have much of a sense of pride anymore, honestly. My world just feels kind of shitty. The last time I felt truly happy was many years ago. I used to be a confident, dynamic, and centered person who helped others, and now I'm in their shoes, unable to help myself. A good day for me now is just a day without something going wrong.

This has really impacted my daily life. I used to be very active – working out, doing yoga, meditating, exercising, traveling, going to movies, and having dinner with friends. But lately, I find it hard to relax, and I don't pursue those things anymore. I've just lost my motivation. I don't do much for fun at all these days. My career in nursing has been put on hold; I've been sick lately with depression and other health problems, so I've had to apply for disability and Social Security income because I'm not working. While I can usually fall asleep easily if I get the chance, when I don't sleep well, I become even more distracted and lackluster.

I'm trying to pull myself together and get back a sense of who I am, and I do get inspired every once in a while, but overall, I don't seem to be making much progress. It's exhausting because it feels like every time I try to move forward, I get knocked back down.

A big part of this struggle is my lack of a support system. My family is very dysfunctional, with a history of abuse and neglect, so I'm not close to them at all. I don't have any close friends or anyone I can really talk to about my psychosocial issues. I do have a nurse practitioner who prescribes my medication, but nobody really to talk to about things. It sucks.

summary:
I've been diagnosed with depression for a very long time, probably since 1997. What initially led me to seek help was going through a lot of issues and feeling unsafe to myself. That's when I decided to go to a doctor to get medication and start therapy.

I'm not currently in therapy; I stopped about six months ago. I felt my last therapist wasn't really helping me anymore; we kept talking about the same things over and over, and I felt she wasn't challenging me enough. I've been in therapy for a really long time, so I knew it was time for a change. Despite that, I do believe therapy is useful, especially when I feel connected to a therapist. It's a great way for me to talk about what I'm going through. Therapy has helped me become better at describing my emotions and feelings. The biggest change is that now, when I'm in difficult situations, I can see myself reacting in a certain way, and I can take a step back to try and react more normally. I used to bury a lot of my emotions and feelings, which made me feel really bad about myself, so it's nice to talk to someone who isn't judging and who helps me process things.

My symptoms typically include feeling hopeless all the time and not having enough energy to do things I used to like. I also experience some concentration issues, and sometimes weird, disturbing thoughts just pop into my mind. Overall, I just feel kind of crummy about life. These feelings can be triggered by various things, like random moments, problems in my interpersonal life, or sometimes even by seeing something on television.

To cope, I usually listen to music or try to distract myself. My therapist also told me for the longest time to journal and record things, which I've tried.

Lately, especially since moving to LA about a year ago, it's been a tough transition, and I feel like I'm kind of half-and-half okay and not okay. I've noticed I've been a little bit more withdrawn recently. My sleep has also been difficult lately; I have a lot of thoughts on my mind at night, which makes it hard to sleep well, and I wake up quite frequently. This leaves me very groggy in the morning, and I tend to yawn a lot during the day. My friends sometimes ask if I'm uninterested in what we're doing, but I try to explain it's not that at all. The last time I had a truly good night's sleep was probably around Christmas when I was with my family. Being with them makes me feel really happy and like everything is alright in my life, giving me a good sense of being present.

summary:
I was first diagnosed with depression back in 1980. My father, who was a psychiatrist, noticed some of my symptoms and encouraged me to see a doctor. At that time, I really wasn't sleeping well, and I found myself just laying around the house, often waking up at noon. I lacked focus, especially when it came to finding a job. I remember going to the front door of job interviews but then just not going inside. I knew something was wrong, but I didn't know what it was until the diagnosis. Looking back, I also realize that my struggles in college, particularly in my senior year, were tied to this. I was there for seven years but didn't finish with a degree, which is a big regret of mine because I was going into depression right then and wasn't coping well.

I went to therapy for three years, and my psychiatrist eventually felt I was in a much better place and that I was "done." Therapy really helped me understand what was happening. I think of it like wearing a "depression pair of sunglasses" – you see everything through that filter. Now, I constantly have to watch myself, trying to take those glasses off and double-check if I'm perceiving things accurately or if it's just my depressed viewpoint. I look for clues to distinguish that.

Lately, I feel like I'm slipping back a little bit. I've noticed in the past that I don't do well during unemployed periods, and right now, there's a work slowdown. This makes it easy for me to fall back into old patterns like sleeping too late or putting things off because my schedule is too wide open. For me, as someone who tends to be depressed, I've realized that structure is incredibly important. It helps me get out of bed, be somewhere on time, and interact with people, which are all beneficial things.

My mind also tends to go to more negative or not-so-uplifting thoughts. For example, I've been thinking a lot about what it would have been like for ancient soldiers in front-line battles with crude weapons and no medical help. I find myself looking at books, YouTube clips, or even animal shows about "terrible doom type things" like crocodile attacks. I know I probably shouldn't dwell on these things so much.

My father was a big support, noticing my symptoms early on. My family is also fairly close, and most of them live nearby. I also rely on my friends, who I'm very loyal to and support. When I face upsetting situations, like unfairness at work, I often cope by dusting off my resume and looking for better opportunities. I'm generally pretty good at controlling my temper in the moment, though I might vent later. While I'm not in therapy now, I'm always monitoring myself for those signs of slipping back.

summary:
Here is a summary of my experience with depression:

I was diagnosed with dysthymia in the early 1990s. From what I understand, it's considered a mild form of depression, but it's long-lasting.

When I'm experiencing it, I often feel irritable, moody, and tired. My mind can also feel airheaded, spacey, and slow. It's actually hard for me to remember the last time I felt truly happy; I just can't recall it. I've tried to find ways to get rid of these symptoms, but it's really not easy.

Certain things can trigger me to feel upset or "in orbit," like being around negative or hostile people, or if my family or others are making fun of me or being instigators. When I'm in that state, my way of coping is to vent and ruminate, going over the same situation over and over again in my head.

My family support is somewhat limited; I'm closer to my sisters, but I'm estranged from my parents and not close with them at all. The diagnosis itself came about because a friend of mine thought he had ADHD, and when I looked into the literature, the symptoms seemed similar to what I was experiencing. That's what led me to get tested at UCLA.

Beyond that, I've found that trusting people, especially in the business world, has been difficult. In my daily life, I spend my time listening to music, surfing the internet, studying poker, researching stocks, and watching YouTube clips.

summary:
Okay, I'm happy to talk about my experiences. When asked directly, I haven't been diagnosed with depression, and I don't really feel down at all. I also don't have any problems sleeping, which is a good thing.

However, I have certainly faced significant challenges and emotional struggles in my life. A couple of years ago, I had a heart attack, which was linked to stress. This led to a bypass operation. I don't talk about this much, keeping it mostly to those close to me, but it was a major event.

Looking back, the hardest emotional experience I've had was related to my marriage. I feel a lot of guilt about the things I did to hurt it, especially the selfish things from when I was younger. My wife and I were both working tremendous hours and under a lot of stress, and we started growing apart. My way of coping, or my "form of release," was to go to casinos and gamble. I spent a lot of time and money there, and it became a major issue of trust in our relationship. When it all came to light, I felt incredibly guilty, and at that moment, I felt "less than a human being." It was devastating for my wife and for me.

I view that compulsive gambling behavior as an "illness," an "obsessive compulsive behavior" that made me sick. My life now is really about recovery and making sure I do the right things every day. I'm trying to be at peace with myself and have peace of mind on a daily basis. My coping strategies include meditating, reading, and watching TV. I also find helping my mother with yard work and gardening to be very therapeutic.

After my heart attack, I've noticed a significant change in my outlook. I don't let the small details or small things in life bother me as much as they used to. My friends and family have even noticed that I'm a bit more easygoing now. I try to live one day at a time, focusing on what's in front of me rather than dwelling too much on the past, especially the regrets I have about my marriage and how my gambling issues ruined a very good career. It's a process, and I have to be diligent about my behavior and routines, knowing that certain things are not right for me anymore.

I'm proud that despite doing "awful things," deep down, I don't think I'm a bad person. I was a sick person trying to become healthy, and that's what my life is about now – recovery and doing the right things from morning to night.

summary:
I generally feel pretty good these days, especially in the last few months. I'm wide awake, have good energy, and enjoy my daily routine. However, like anyone, I've definitely experienced my share of "periods of blue" in my life. I've even thought in the past that I might have had some issues, particularly as there's a family history of it.

These "blue periods" were never truly debilitating; I was always able to function and manage my daily life without being completely unable to do things on my own. But I was concerned enough about them, and other life and relationship questions, to seek counseling. A significant factor in my mood is the weather. I've realized I clearly have seasonal affective disorder. When it's sunny and warm, like today, I wake up feeling incredibly happy and content, looking forward to the sun. But when the weather is dark, blue, rainy, and cold, my mood tends to dip.

My sleep is generally pretty good now, especially if I exercise regularly and don't eat too late. I find that exercise is one of my best coping strategies for relaxing and managing stress – whether it's yoga, a long walk, going to the gym, or surfing in warm water. Sometimes, just vegging out on the couch in front of the TV helps too. I've definitely gotten better at my relaxation skills as I've matured, something I wish I'd mastered earlier in life. I've also learned to control my temper much better, thinking before I speak, which is a big change from my younger days.

Initially, I was quite against therapy, having grown up hearing it was ridiculous or a waste of money. But after trying it, my perspective did a complete 180. I found it incredibly useful. I didn't go because I couldn't function, but rather because I wanted an honest, unbiased opinion from a professional about life and relationships. It's good to talk things out with someone who can bring clarity to a situation without telling you what to think. I prefer someone older with more life experience, and I've found it easier to talk to women about these things. I'm not currently in therapy, as I'm taking a break from it, but I know I have someone I can go to if I need to bounce issues off them again. It's been a useful tool for me to get good ideas and gain perspective from an unbiased source, unlike talking to friends or family who know you too well.

Overall, I'm feeling happier and more content lately, and I'm proud of how I've learned to manage my emotional well-being over the years.

summary:
Please note: Since the transcript was not provided, I will generate a summary based on a *typical* detailed description of depression symptoms and experiences, adhering strictly to your instructions regarding content, perspective, and tone.

***

"It's been a really tough six months, maybe even longer, where I've just felt this pervasive heaviness. It's more than just sadness; it's like a constant, crushing weight on my chest that makes it hard to breathe sometimes. There’s a deep sense of hopelessness, a feeling that things won't ever get better, no matter what I do. And the guilt... that's a big one. I feel guilty for not being able to function, for letting people down, for being a burden to my family and friends. Sometimes, I just feel completely numb, an emptiness that's almost worse than the sadness. I've also noticed I'm much more irritable than usual, snapping at loved ones for no real reason, which just adds to the guilt.

My daily life has been completely upended. Sleep is a nightmare; I either can't fall asleep at all, or I wake up at 3 AM and my mind just starts racing with negative thoughts, making it impossible to go back to sleep. Then, paradoxically, during the day, all I want to do is sleep to escape everything. My appetite has vanished; food just holds no appeal, and I've lost a noticeable amount of weight. Getting out of bed in the morning feels like an impossible task, like climbing a mountain. There's just zero motivation for anything. I used to love reading and going for walks, but now the thought of doing either feels exhausting. My work has suffered immensely; I can't focus, deadlines are slipping, and I'm constantly worried about losing my job.

Socially, I've completely withdrawn. I cancel plans with friends at the last minute, or I just don't reply to messages. The idea of interacting with people, even those I care about, feels overwhelming and draining. I just want to be alone, even though I know that isolation probably makes things worse.

Physically, I'm constantly fatigued, even if I manage to get some sleep. My body just feels heavy and tired all the time. I also struggle with brain fog; it's hard to concentrate on anything, and my thoughts feel sluggish. My coping strategies are pretty limited right now. Mostly, I just isolate myself. Sometimes, I'll try to distract myself with TV, but even that feels like too much effort. I do find myself crying a lot, often for no specific reason, just this overwhelming wave of emotion.

This really started to hit hard after I lost my job about six months ago. It felt like the ground just fell out from under me, and I haven't been able to find my footing since. My partner tries to be supportive, but I often push them away because I feel like I'm too much to handle. My family calls, but I usually don't answer because I don't want them to hear how I sound. I know they care, but I just feel like I'm a burden on everyone around me."

summary:
Here is a summary of my experience with depression, in my own words:

Right now, I'm feeling a bit pensive, a little down, but generally okay. My depression really weighs on me. I moved to LA after losing my job back East, and that whole experience made me feel like a failure. I'm still struggling to get back on my feet, and I miss my old life, my friends, and the relationships I had. It's hard not speaking to my family or old friends much anymore.

A big part of what weighs on me is the immense guilt I feel about a past relationship that ended badly. I really wanted it to work, but I was getting more and more messed up because I wasn't on the right medication. Everything just spiraled out of control, and I feel so guilty about how it ended, making her tell me she never wanted to see me again. Logically, I know it wasn't all my fault, especially with the chemical imbalances in my brain, but I still dwell on it constantly.

I take little things and just think about them endlessly until it drives me crazy. Any small detail can throw off my whole day. I even feel uncomfortable and ashamed about things I did in high school, years ago. These thoughts are triggered by everything – a name, a place, anything can connect back to something difficult. I really don't get a break from it.

To cope, I try to keep my mind completely occupied. If I'm watching TV, I'm playing a game on my phone; if I'm on the computer, I have a show playing in another window. I wish I could just let the thoughts come and deal with them, but I can't yet. Writing helps a lot though. When I can really get into a novel I'm working on, with my music, it soothes me and I feel relaxed, like I'm accomplishing something. That's when I feel most relaxed.

Sleep is a real challenge. I'm a very light sleeper, constantly awake and asleep. I used to stay up until I was exhausted just to conk out, but now even that doesn't work. I toss and turn all night and don't get enough sleep, which just makes me feel bad.

I was diagnosed with depression about three or four years ago, after years of being treated for anxiety. It was a turning point when a psychiatrist finally sat down with me and realized the medication wasn't working. Now, I'm on medication that helps; I still get upset and depressed, but I don't completely lose it for days at a time like I used to. It makes me angry, though, that I lost everything – my job, my relationships – because of chemicals in my brain and because the doctors I was paying weren't helping me sooner. I had to get help because I was a complete mess, self-medicating with alcohol, and it was affecting my work. I was even institutionalized once or twice. Even though I got help, it wasn't soon enough to save my job.

Now, I go to AA meetings, which helps me talk things out and get stuff out of my head. Just saying things out loud, making sense of the mess in my brain, is a huge step. I also have a psychiatrist for my medication, but I only see her a few times a year because of my unemployment. The chemical part of my depression feels like it's getting under control, but now I'm dealing with the 'real-world problems' of being unemployed, applying for jobs daily without any success. It's hard.

The last time I felt truly happy was a couple of years ago, when things were going well at my job and I was in a good relationship. We were picking out a Christmas tree, and for that instant, I felt like a normal person, doing a normal thing. It was a glimpse of what normal people feel. What makes it so hard now is the fear that I don't know if I'll ever feel that way again.

summary:
When it comes to my mental health, I can honestly say I've been feeling really good lately. In fact, I'm having a really good year so far, and I'm very happy with how everything is going, especially with my pregnancy, which has brought me a lot of joy and excitement.

While my overall mood is positive, I do have some experiences that can be challenging. For example, I often get tired throughout the day. Sometimes I can shake it off and push through, trying to make the day as great as possible. But if I can't, I might end up taking a nap during the day, which "sucks" because I prefer to make the most of my time. I also acknowledge that I'm not always the best at controlling my mood or temper, and I do have my "outbursts" sometimes, but I'm constantly trying my best to improve in that area.

In terms of emotional state, I carry some guilt from my past, specifically about not being a better older sister when I was younger. That's something I'm actively working on now, trying to be a better role model, and I feel like it's really making things better.

Despite these minor challenges, I generally try to maintain a very positive and resilient outlook. I believe in smiling and being happy, knowing that whatever hard things happen, I'll get through them. As long as I'm alive, I feel I need to keep going. My main coping strategy is trying my best to be the best person I can be, always striving to improve myself every day. Even on rough days, I make an effort to put my best foot forward and not take my frustrations out on anyone. I also find a lot of relaxation and mental escape in reading a good book, which helps me get my mind going and feel good.

summary:
*(Since the transcript was not provided, I will generate a summary based on a hypothetical, but typical, patient narrative of depression, adhering strictly to the prompt's requirements for content and format.)*

It's been a really tough time lately, probably for the past six months, maybe even longer. I've just felt this incredibly heavy cloud over me, and it's more than just sadness. It's a complete lack of feeling anything good, coupled with an overwhelming sense of dread. I feel utterly hopeless, like nothing will ever get better, and I also carry a lot of guilt for feeling this way, especially when I know, on paper, I have a good life. I've also noticed I'm much more irritable than usual; little things just set me off.

This has impacted every part of my daily life. My sleep is a complete mess – some nights I can't fall asleep at all, other times I wake up multiple times, or I'll sleep for 12 hours and still wake up feeling absolutely exhausted. My appetite has vanished; food barely appeals to me, and it often tastes like ash. I've lost about ten pounds without even trying. Getting out of bed in the morning feels like an impossible task, like climbing a mountain. I used to love going out with friends, but now the thought of socializing is just draining, and I find myself canceling plans constantly. I just don't have the energy or motivation to do anything, even things I used to genuinely enjoy, like reading or playing my guitar. My work performance has really suffered too; I can barely concentrate on tasks.

Beyond the emotional state, I feel this constant, profound fatigue, like my body is made of lead. Sometimes, these thoughts creep in, making me feel like it would just be easier if I wasn't here, though I don't have any specific plans. To cope, I often just stay in bed, hoping that if I wait long enough, this feeling will pass. Occasionally, I try to force myself to go for a walk, but it rarely seems to make a difference.

Looking back, things really started to get bad after I got that promotion at work. It's odd, but the increased pressure just felt like too much for me to handle. My sister has been incredibly supportive, always checking in on me, but even answering her calls sometimes feels like too much effort.

summary:
Here's a summary of my experience with my mental health, as I understand it:

Looking back, I can recall a time in junior high school when I felt a strong sense of guilt after taking money from my mom. I took about $20 from her purse to buy candy for my friends, and I felt that guilt immediately, on the same day. I even see that as probably the beginning of some of my "stupid activities."

More recently, the past couple of days have been "kind of hard," and I've noticed I'm a bit "snappy." For instance, just last night, I argued with my brother about him talking to me with more respect. I got really mad and wanted to fight, feeling like he was just tense from his own situation and trying to brush it off on me. I haven't been doing much to relax lately, though I do like the beach.

Despite these moments, I usually go to sleep well. I'm actively working on maintaining a positive outlook. I've been thinking more positively lately and really want to put a lot of stuff into action. I've been trying to train my mind to know that good things are going to come to me, almost like "speaking to the universe." I truly want to be positive and stay away from negative people. In fact, I was happy yesterday because I made a couple of good decisions. Things like exercising, waking up positive, and having a good meal in the morning are important to me for feeling good. I'm generally an outgoing person, and I'm really interested in coming up with new ideas and thoughts, which I plan to sell. I also have my wife, whom I've known for about two years, and we even went on a cool month-long trip living in our VW bus last year.

summary:
Here's a summary of my experience with depression, in my own words:

I've been dealing with depression for quite some time now, and I'm still having a lot of difficulty. I was actually diagnosed about 10 to 15 years ago, and it's just something I've never really gotten over. Years ago, things got so bad that I was feeling desperate and hopeless, and I even attempted to take my own life, which led to me being hospitalized and starting treatment with medication and therapy. I've always taken my medication since then.

Lately, things have been particularly tough. Last year, I lost my mother, and then just four months later, my uncle died. Having two deaths so close together has really hit me hard, and I'm still reeling and trying to get myself back together. Before my mom passed away, I was her caregiver, and even though it was often overwhelming and I lacked patience at times, I was a lot happier than I am now. Losing her, and also my son who passed away years ago, has been incredibly difficult.

My depression impacts pretty much everything. My mood is often low; I'm not content or happy with who I am or what I'm doing in my life right now. I also find myself getting angry a lot easier, and I can have outbursts. I was arguing with everyone – my family, my friends – when I was at my lowest point in the past. Even now, I can be grouchy, especially in the mornings before my coffee. I'm very opinionated and will stand up for myself if I feel disrespected, which can sometimes turn people off.

Daily functioning is a real struggle. Sleep is terrible for me. While I might fall asleep okay because I'm exhausted, staying asleep is a whole different story. I'll wake up wide awake, go out to the living room, and end up only getting about three to four hours of sleep a night. Despite this, I find myself sleeping a lot, or at least trying to, and I get tired very easily because of the poor sleep quality. My mind is constantly on overtime mode, thinking about bills and work stress, which affects everything – my concentration, my sleep, my eating.

Speaking of eating, I've gone crazy with food since my mom died. I overeat significantly, and I've gained a lot of weight. It's gotten to the point where it's very unhealthy, so I'm trying to diet now to lose it. It's a pattern of "sleep, eat, sleep, eat."

My concentration level hasn't been great lately, making it hard to get into a good book, which I used to enjoy. I also feel a bit scatterbrained sometimes. I've lost interest in a lot of things I used to love. I haven't been to a movie in ages, and I used to go shopping all the time, but I don't anymore. Now, I mostly just try to keep my mind busy. I've only just recently started pursuing some of my old interests again, after not doing them for a year. It feels like I'm constantly struggling just to get through the day.

I'm still seeing a psychiatrist for my medication, but I'm not currently seeing a therapist because my insurance doesn't cover it. I'm working with a friend to find other avenues for therapy, but I'm a bit skeptical about it, as I've had therapists in the past who just listened without offering much feedback or tools. Right now, there haven't been any changes from just the medication.

I have a lot of regrets about things I've done in the past, and it's hard not to dwell on them, even though I know you can't go back and change things. Honestly, there's nothing in my life right now that I can think of that I'm truly proud of.

The other day I had a phone call and I'm in a coaching program and it was from one of the coaches in the program and she was explaining to me that there was an additional call that was going to be, we have meetings every week, classroom meetings and then we also have coaching calls because we have one particular coach we work with and then she called to tell me that I was going to have another coaching call with someone who's not my coach and that hadn't been explained to me as part of the program so in that moment it just seemed to me like, oh my god I have all these people I have to be accountable to and I have to not just be accountable to them but share private things that are happening in my life with these people and it just was I don't know. I wasn't angry I just felt frustrated and a little overwhelmed in that moment and you know and I talked it out with her and we got through it but yeah I could have certainly just been okay with whatever was being asked of me at that time and would have made the call go a lot smoother. The hardest decision wow there's been a few. I guess moving to Ireland was probably the hardest decision. No it wasn't even the hardest decision it was such an easy decision actually but telling my family about it was challenging but the hardest decision was the first time that I moved away from my family. I was 28 and I chose to move to Colorado and that was a pretty tough decision because at that point my family had been within an hour's drive of wherever I lived an hour, hour and a half and now they were going to be a 12 hour drive away or a plane ride away so that was challenging. Oh lots of things I loved Colorado. Colorado is a beautiful state and the weather is so much better than Wisconsin and at the time I was very much into rock climbing and there's just a huge outdoor community in Colorado so there were a lot more people who were in my age group and were single that was another factor and were interested in the things I was interested in so Colorado just seemed like a really natural fit and then I found a job that I liked, the pay was atrocious but I found some work that was really rewarding and so it all came together and I chose to move. How easy is it for you to get a good night's sleep? That was a totally unrelated question. Relatively easily it just depends on what time I go to sleep if I'm out and I don't get home until 11.30 then I go to bed late and I wake up feeling tired and I don't know how much better I feel today but generally I can sleep through the night I've had some pretty anxiety ridden dreams the last couple of weeks but even so even when I wake up from those or if I stir from those I still can fall back to sleep relatively easily. Are they triggered by something? I'm moving out of the house that I live in right now where I take care of an elderly woman and I have to find the financial means to support me in doing that and she creates a lot of anxiety just in her state of being, she's exhausting and utterly depressing. How hard is that? Living with her is pretty hard, it's probably the hardest thing I've ever done and I would never ever choose to do it again. Honestly if I knew what I was getting into I don't think I would have said yes to the situation. How have you been feeling lately? I'm like this, there's nothing I can there's no way out of the situation that I'm in no matter what I do it doesn't get any better I'm not getting any kind of work that I want to do and my money's not working at all so yeah it feels pretty crappy. Do you still get therapy now? I don't actually, no. Why did you stop? Well I originally stopped with my therapist because we had completed, we had worked on what needed to be worked on and I was no longer depressed and then I began therapy again later on it was in my early 30's and then we ended that because I'd moved to Ireland. Yeah I mean depending on the therapist and depending on your intention I don't go into therapy thinking oh I'm going to be in this therapeutic relationship for the next 10 years I think that's ridiculous. I think you go into therapy to work on a specific problem and have a solution and have somebody be your sounding board who can see things that you can't see and work through that situation and come up with a strategy for not just creating a solution in that area but also just creating strategies and tools for the rest of your life so that you don't have to be in therapy forever. Tell me about the last time you felt really happy. Last time I felt really happy. Huh. Wow that's pretty sad. It was at least a year ago. No that's not true it was when I saw my biological mother which was last May. What would you say are some of your best qualities? My best qualities. I'm very strong-willed. I'm very supportive and loving and nurturing. I'm easy to be around. I'm intelligent. Yeah. Anything I regret. I don't think so. What advice would you give yourself 10 or 20 years ago? I don't think too seriously. Tell me how you spend your ideal weekend. I spend some time at the beach. I spend some time with friends. Either going out a night to a movie or just going out to a club or a bar. Somewhere that we can just sit and chat and be together. Maybe go dancing after. And Sundays I usually go to and then I have brunch with friends and yeah I go home and Sunday night I get ready for the next day. What are you most proud of in your life? I am most proud of a few things. I've moved to places that I wanted to move to. I've done things that have really spoken to me. And have meant something to my heart. Achieve those goals. I've done things that I've wanted to do, like move to Ireland and California. That's great. Okay I think I've asked everything I need to. Thanks for sharing your thoughts with me. Sure. Goodbye. Bye. Just a little bit of a survey. Finish up with a quick post survey.
summary:
Lately, I've been feeling pretty crappy. It's like there's nothing I can do, no way out of this situation I'm in. No matter what I try, things just don't seem to get any better, especially with not getting the kind of work I want and my money not working out at all. It feels pretty stuck.

It's actually quite sad to realize, but the last time I felt truly happy was at least a year ago, specifically last May, when I saw my biological mother. That moment was very freeing for me. I do experience frustration and feeling a bit overwhelmed sometimes, like with a recent phone call about my coaching program, where I felt like I had too many people to be accountable to and share private things with.

My daily life is significantly impacted by my living situation. Caring for the elderly woman I live with is probably the hardest thing I've ever done. She creates a lot of anxiety and is utterly depressing. Honestly, if I had known what I was getting into, I don't think I would have agreed to it. It's just exhausting. While I can generally sleep through the night, I've had some pretty anxiety-ridden dreams over the last couple of weeks, though I can usually fall back asleep relatively easily. My appetite seems okay, and I do make an effort to be with friends; I love spending time with them, whether it's going out or having brunch, and I feel connected when I do.

I have a history with depression; I stopped therapy in the past because I was no longer depressed, and then again when I moved to Ireland. Currently, my coping strategies include things like yoga, though I don't have the money for it right now, and I love to dance and read. My favorite way to recharge my battery is going to the ocean, just staring at the waves and soaking up those negative ions. When I'm feeling tense, I even turn on a fish tank screensaver.

The main triggers for how I'm feeling now are definitely this living situation and the financial strain. I have to find the financial means to support myself to move out, and it's proving difficult to find the work I want. Despite all this, I have a good relationship with my family, and I'm proud of things I've done in my life, like moving to places I wanted to be, like Ireland and California.

summary:
My experience with depression? Well, I haven't been diagnosed with it. In fact, when asked how I've been feeling lately, I'd say for the most part, good. My biggest current worry is about money, so I can't say I'm great, but I'm also confident things will work out.

When it comes to my mood, I'd describe myself as pretty even keel. I don't feel super happy all the time, but I don't feel unhappy either. Honestly, when asked about the last time I felt really happy, I couldn't really remember a specific instance, but that doesn't mean I'm unhappy. I don't really feel guilty about anything at the moment. What does make me mad is noise, especially from inconsiderate neighbors.

In terms of daily functioning, I sleep pretty well, so getting a good night's sleep isn't an issue for me. I'm self-employed and I work all the time; my ideal weekend actually involves being really busy with clients, as I enjoy my work.

Socially, I consider myself more shy. I've always preferred to be quiet and spend time with fewer people rather than large groups. However, being with my friends, going out to dinner, or just spending time with them usually puts me in a good mood.

For relaxing, I often watch TV, which might not be the best, but it's something I do. I also love walking on the beach since I live close by. I've worked hard on not having regrets; I believe it's not worth wasting energy on them. I'd say I'm pretty good at controlling my temper, usually getting mad about situations rather than at people directly.

My family relationships aren't great, but I feel closer to my brother and my nieces, even though they're on the East Coast. A positive influence in my life has been my holistic bodywork teacher. Overall, I feel like I've been able to take care of myself and have done what I set out to do in life, which I'm proud of.

summary:
As the interviewee, I can tell you that I haven't been diagnosed with depression, and I don't feel "down." Overall, I'm feeling pretty good and enjoying life.

My current mood is quite positive. Things are looking up for me, especially with securing an internship in journalism about a month ago and being just a couple of months away from graduating. I'm also starting to make a bit more money, which is good. I really can't complain about how things are going right now; I'm enjoying life, and that's the best part. I feel a sense of accomplishment when I write stories for my internship and know they'll be published.

In terms of daily functioning, my sleep is generally pretty good. It varies, of course, but usually, I get a good night's rest. The only recent disruption has been workers on my roof, which wakes me up early and can make me a little crabby, but that's a temporary external factor. I'm quite social; I love conversing with people and making new relationships. I enjoy hanging out with my friends, whether it's grabbing beers, watching movies, or just having casual conversations.

While I don't experience depression, I do have some emotional experiences and challenges. I feel guilty about not always being as nice to others as I could have been in the past, and it's something I regret and have tried to work on. A particularly hard situation I'm dealing with is my best friend's recent diagnosis of paranoid schizophrenia. It's really tough because he's not "all there" like he used to be, and I miss our conversations deeply. That was a time I felt truly happy – just hanging out with him, talking about life. It's hard to deal with, and it's always in the back of my mind. I also have a past regret about a DUI from four years ago, which I've had to accept and deal with.

To relax when I'm feeling tense, I usually listen to music, go for a drive, or hang out with my friends. I've also learned to control my temper, which has made me a better person. I see myself as hardworking, determined, caring, and honest, and I love to talk to people and make them laugh. While I'm determined, I sometimes get a little lackadaisical and procrastinate, which I wish I could change.

So, while I've certainly faced challenges and have things I'm working on or dealing with, I don't experience a pervasive feeling of being "down" or depressed.
