summary:
I'm feeling pretty good today, just hanging out. My life in Los Angeles can be really hectic and chaotic, like a constant grind, which isn't very conducive for a supportive community. That's a big reason why I love to travel – it helps me escape the city's 'made up ties and restraints' and see the world as it truly is. I even worked at a hot spring resort in Los Banos for a while, where there were no phones or Wi-Fi, just raw, real people, hiking, farming, and carpentry. It was sanity.

Currently, I'm studying physical therapy, which I'm passionate about, and I'm about to become a licensed massage therapist. I used to pursue music composition, but the crazy tuition hikes forced me to leave; I wasn't going to trap myself with federal loans. My dream is to alleviate the 'nightmare' of metropolitan cities and bring back 'dream' through physical therapy and artistic expression. I consider myself outgoing and love experiencing new things.

When it comes to my emotional state, I've been kind of cruising on what I call a 'gray line.' Some people might not like this, but I actually find it to be a really nice hue – it feels stable and comfortable. I haven't really felt the feeling of guilt in a long time, which is tough. I experience a lot of happiness, like this morning biking in the sun, and I also feel a lot of sadness. But for me, it's all part of the human experience. I think everyone is depressed, overjoyed, angry, shy, and social all at the same time, just on different days, different variants, different floats. So, yes, I think I'm depressed, but I also think I'm really happy, angry, and friendly – it just depends on the moment.

Sometimes, if I get too caught up in my thoughts, it can take me a while to get to sleep. To relax and get grounded, I practice breathing exercises, go through my mantras, or do my 'pre-dream therapy work.' I also find it helpful to make chamomile tea or a smoothie, or go for a bike ride. Occasionally, medical cannabis, specifically indica, helps me get drowsy. It's about relieving myself of 'bad juju.'

I haven't been diagnosed with depression by a medical professional. My immediate family is important to me; my mom really understands me, and my sister and I are close. My relationship with my dad is still developing, but I connect with him through his art. I also collaborate a lot with other artists, which I'm very comfortable with. Overall, I feel pretty good and enjoy my life, even with its challenges.

summary:
Here is a summary of my experience with depression, in my own words:

I've been diagnosed with depression, and lately, I've just been feeling a little bit upset and generally depressed. My main symptoms involve keeping myself locked in and not talking to anyone. I really regret how my life has turned out; I wish I had a more normal, stable life with friends and loved ones, and an actual relationship, but I don't.

My past has made me shy, and I have a lot of trouble making new friends and trusting people. This often leads to me pushing people away. Whenever someone gets too involved in my life, I tend to say or do something to make them want to stay away from me, and I really wish I had handled all those situations differently. I don't have a relationship with any of my family either; we really don't talk.

Getting a good night's sleep isn't easy for me; it usually takes a few hours to finally fall asleep once I lay down. I've also had nightmares about my childhood, involving my biological father, and my stepfather when I was 16.

To cope, I try to avoid stress as much as possible. I've removed a bunch of stressful things from my life, like bills, and I'm trying to incorporate new things to minimize stress. I also tried seeing a therapist, but I just got rid of them because I didn't feel like they were really listening or providing much beneficial help. Now, I'm looking for alternative ways to cope, like listening to music and forcing myself to go to different social related events, even though it's hard.

One significant way I manage my social needs is by playing online multiplayer games. I feel that the best way to keep people in my life is by having 'fake people' in my life through avatars and usernames. I have somewhat fun going to these virtual worlds and talking to people that way, because they don't know who I really am or even my real name. It's a way to connect without the difficulties of real-life trust and intimacy.

My ideal weekend often involves solitary activities like going to Starbucks or McDonald's to get online and play games, then maybe seeing a movie, relaxing, or driving to a new place alone. I wish I was healthier, looked better, and had better eyesight, but most of all, I wish I had a bunch of people in my life I could call friends.

summary:
I've been diagnosed as a classic depressive, probably about six years ago. My wife was a big part of me seeking help back then; she really pushed me into it. At the time, I was just having a lot of trouble with the struggle, a general displeasure with my life.

Lately, I've been feeling very anxious. A lot of that comes from financial stress. I have big bills to pay and not a lot of income coming in, and I really worry about falling behind and losing ground. The stakes feel high, and it's a very uncomfortable position to be in.

When it comes to my mood, I can't really recall the last time I felt truly happy. Even when I get an acting gig, which is something I want to do, I only feel mildly happy, and often those experiences turn out to be disappointing anyway. I'm just never over-excited with happiness. I can also get very upset at times.

My daily functioning is impacted too. Sleep is a bit of an issue; I sometimes self-medicate to go to sleep, though I probably don't have to. About half the nights, I wake up much earlier than I'd like. On nights when I work until two or three in the morning, I only get five or six hours of sleep instead of the seven I need, and that leaves me feeling sluggish and not quite as functional as I'd like to be, even if I try to cope pretty well. My wife and I also haven't been sleeping in the same bed for about three years.

My career has been a long road. I was in another business for 25 years, and only now am I finally getting around to acting, which was my original dream. It feels like I can't put it off anymore, partly due to the economy. I also regret not pushing my previous business harder years ago, feeling like it's "dead" today. Job hunting is difficult, and my wife and I often argue about my methods because we're very different in our approaches. There was also a time I missed an opportunity to introduce myself to a famous person at a nightclub because I wasn't sure if it would be appropriate, and I regret that.

To cope, I do see a therapist, and I find it useful. It's something I look forward to because I feel like I'm talking to someone who understands me. My current therapist isn't trying to prescribe drugs, though previous ones have. For relaxation, I read, cook, and listen to talk radio. There's also a past experience I wish I could erase from my memory—meeting a particular woman when I first moved to LA who left me "less than healthy physically."

Here's a summary of my experience with depression, in my own words:

"Right now, I'm feeling kind of down, and lately, I've been really frustrated. A big part of it is that I'm poor, and I don't want to be. I don't have a boyfriend, and money is a constant struggle. I've noticed I'm just more sad than usual.

It's been a really long time since I felt truly happy – honestly, it's been over two years. The last time I felt that way was when I didn't have any money problems and was doing fine. My financial situation impacts so much; it's hard to get my own place in LA, so I have to live with roommates, which has its own challenges, like a recent move because of a roommate's marijuana plants.

When it comes to daily life, I can get a good night's sleep now if my roommates don't have the TV on, but if I don't sleep well, I'm tired and lazier during the day. I try to relax by watching funny TV shows like Big Bang Theory or a funny movie. Sometimes, when I'm tense, I even put on a fish tank screensaver.

I've had some tough decisions, like leaving home in Florida to try for a better life out here in California, but I do miss home. It's uncomfortable for me to talk about that. My relationship with my family is something I'd rather not discuss. I've also had past relationship issues, like with an ex-boyfriend, but I'm over him now.

I haven't been diagnosed with depression, but these feelings of sadness, frustration, and a lack of happiness have been present for a significant time, mostly tied to my money situation and living circumstances. I try to persevere, and I've learned from a past mentor to never complain and be thankful for everything I have, even though it's hard sometimes."

summary:
I'm doing well today, and generally, I'd say I've been feeling normal and fine lately, with no complaints. I haven't noticed any significant changes in my behavior or thoughts; things have been pretty much the same as ever. In fact, I haven't been diagnosed with depression, nor with PTSD.

Just last night, I was really happy hanging out with my friends, sharing stories and laughing. Spending time with them, watching good movies, people-watching, and listening to music are things that usually put me in a good mood. My best friends would probably describe me as funny, easy to get along with, and caring. My ideal weekend is pretty relaxed, just sitting around reading, going to the movies, or watching TV.

While my mood is generally stable, I do feel bad when people write negative comments about my writing online. I also carry a bit of guilt about not talking to my grandparents as much as I feel I should, especially since they largely raised me and my grandmother was a strong, positive influence in my life. The death of my sister was also a really traumatizing experience for me. I also went through a hard divorce, but I feel I made the right decision. Overall, I'm satisfied with myself, my friends, and my place in the world, and I'm proud to feel comfortable with that.

When it comes to daily functioning, getting a good night's sleep isn't always super easy, mostly because I tend to go to bed too late. When I don't sleep well, I feel foggy, distracted, and have trouble concentrating. I also admit that sometimes I can be kind of lazy and wish I had a better work ethic; I tend to procrastinate and put things off until the last minute or even after they're due.

To relax or when I'm feeling tense, I'll turn on a fish tank screensaver, lay down, try some deep breathing, or just watch TV. I'm pretty good at controlling my temper; I don't let anger show much and consider myself rational.

summary:
Here's a summary of my experience, as if I were the interviewee:

"Lately, I've been feeling quite stressed and worried. A significant part of this stems from my career struggles and the financial difficulties I'm currently facing. It's become very challenging, and I feel a lot of guilt about not generating as much income as I need to right now. This financial pressure, along with a regret about not taking my career more seriously earlier in life, makes things much harder for me now.

Sometimes, I even experience disturbing thoughts, though I'm not always aware of what triggers them. I also wish I could be a bit stronger and more assertive in general. When I'm feeling tense, I sometimes turn on my fish tank screen saver to relax, or I just stay home, maybe watch a movie in bed.

Despite these challenges, I seem to get a good night's sleep almost every night, which is something I don't struggle with. However, if I don't sleep well, I tend to be grumpy and lethargic in the morning.

My life has had its share of difficult moments that weigh on me. One of the hardest decisions I ever made was choosing not to have a child, largely due to financial burden and the father's wishes. I also experienced being raped, which is an event I wish I could erase from my memory, though I haven't been diagnosed with PTSD or depression. My relationship with my father has also been difficult; he's mostly been out of my life, and while I'm used to it, it's still not the best situation, and I wish it could be remedied.

Being a parent to my stepchildren is also challenging at times, as I try to navigate how much to get involved. I make a conscious effort not to punish them excessively or scream at them, unlike how I was treated as a child.

Despite these struggles, I have a strong support system. I'm fortunate to have lots of friends and family here in Los Angeles, and I consider myself a very loyal, honest, and caring friend who loves deeply. I've also had incredible experiences, like living in Greece and traveling the world. I recently felt absolutely fantastic, happy, relaxed, and free on a holiday in Cancun, like I didn't have a care in the world, even if it was just temporary. I am actively working very hard to remedy my financial situation, exploring many ways to generate more money, both within and outside my career."

summary:
I haven't been diagnosed with depression. Lately, I've been feeling pretty run down, slower, more tired, and a little out of it, but that's really because my mother-in-law is dying. We've spent a lot of time in the hospital recently, which means I haven't had much time to sleep. My sleep usually depends on how much exercise I get; if I'm active, it's pretty easy to sleep well, but if not, it's harder. Right now, the lack of sleep just makes me feel a bit slow and out of it.

Emotionally, I do feel some guilt about moving to California and leaving my family in Virginia. Even though I know I shouldn't, they always seem to miss me, and it sometimes feels like I abandoned them, even if I don't miss Virginia itself. My temper is generally pretty good, though I do get upset if I feel someone isn't listening to me.

Despite feeling tired from the current situation, I can still find happiness pretty easily, especially when I'm having a fun day, either on my own or with my wife. Getting outside, hiking, and exercising are things I enjoy and find easy to do. My weekends are often spent hiking, visiting parks, taking pictures of wildlife, and then watching movies or dancing at night with my wife. I have a very good and close relationship with my wife, parents, and in-laws, with no problems.

My biggest current challenge is a back injury from work. It holds me back from doing a lot of things I used to love, like gymnastics and trampoline, and I can't work out as much as I'd like because of the pain. I wish I could get back into the shape I used to be. This physical limitation affects my activity more than my mood does. I'm proud of moving to LA and making a life here, as it was a big decision to leave my comfort zone in Virginia. I wouldn't say I have any regrets, but I do wish I'd had more time to figure out my career path without pressure.

summary:
Here's a summary of my experience with depression, as if I am the interviewee:

"When it comes to how I'm doing, I've noticed some changes in myself over time. For example, I used to really enjoy traveling when I was young, the whole experience of it. But now, I don't enjoy the traveling anymore at all; it's just about getting to the destination point. That enjoyment of the journey itself is just gone.

Sometimes, when I'm feeling tense, I find myself turning to simple things to cope. I'll put on a fish tank screensaver. I know it's not Hawaii, but it's the best I've got. It feels a bit sad, almost like a fear, that this is my go-to.

Looking back, my second marriage is a situation I often think about, and I wish I had handled it differently. The main issue was around having children. I already had my kids from my first marriage and had told her initially I didn't want more. She said she didn't either, but then her best friend got pregnant, and our relationship really changed. I basically wouldn't relent on the children issue, and we ended up getting divorced. I realize now I wasn't very flexible in that process, and it's something I wish I could change about myself.

In general, there's another part of me I'd really like to change: if I don't like someone, it can be very difficult for me to interact with them. It's something that has caused issues in the past, and I'd very much like to change that about myself."

summary:
Here is a summary of my experience with depression:

Lately, I've been feeling really down, more than usual. It's like a heavy cloud is constantly over me, and I just can't shake this profound sadness. The hopelessness is probably the worst part; I truly feel like nothing will ever get better. This intense feeling has been going on for about two months now, and I think it started getting worse after I lost my job – that really hit me hard.

I've completely lost interest in everything I used to enjoy. My hobbies, even just watching TV, it all feels pointless. Getting out of bed in the morning has become a monumental task; I just want to stay under the covers all day. My sleep is a mess – I either can't fall asleep, or I wake up multiple times during the night, leaving me exhausted all day. My appetite has also gone down significantly; I barely eat because food just doesn't appeal to me anymore, and I've lost weight without even trying.

I've found myself isolating a lot. I cancel plans with friends because I just don't have the energy to pretend to be okay. And I feel so guilty about it, like I'm letting everyone down, and like I'm a burden, even though my family has been supportive and tries to encourage me. I do try to go for walks sometimes, just to get some fresh air, but it usually doesn't help much, and it's hard to even motivate myself for that. I just want to feel like myself again, but I don't know how.

summary:
Here's a summary of my experience with depression, from my perspective:

I was diagnosed with depression over five years ago. What really got me into it was a profound lack of motivation, and my symptoms pretty much paralleled what you'd expect from depression. Specifically, I experienced a significant loss of appetite, a complete lack of motivation to do anything, and a strong aversion to social interaction. I even developed a fear of social situations. Those were the main four or five symptoms that really defined that period for me.

I'm not in therapy anymore. I stopped because I felt like I had moved past a chapter in my life where doctors were taking control of my health and experimenting with drugs. I decided to take an alternative route. I started juicing more and really tried to listen to what my body needed, with the help of the internet and nutrition experts. I do believe therapy is useful, though. I think it's incredibly helpful for overall mental health because it allows you to look inward, or have someone help you do that, which is essential for readjusting to problems that might otherwise just resonate in your subconscious until they have an outburst.

Lately, I've been feeling much better than I have in a long time. I genuinely believe this improvement is due to a transition in my diet. I don't think it's a placebo effect; I feel like it's actually helping to loosen up toxins and things that have accumulated over my lifetime from unhealthy food choices and other substances. While I've made progress, I still struggle with controlling my hunger, especially when I get really upset. It can be a problem, and I have to work to calm myself down. Sometimes I just don't stop eating. My best friend might describe me as calm, but also perhaps a bit sad, though they'd also say I'm smart and talented. I also carry some guilt about not supporting my friends as much as I could with their career choices. Despite these ongoing challenges, I'm most proud of where I am right now; I never imagined I'd be in such a fortunate situation.

summary:
Here's a summary of my experience with depression, based on our conversation:

"When it comes to my mental health, I haven't been diagnosed with depression, and I don't really feel like I experience it. I'd say I'm generally pretty happy, usually on an 'even keel' unless something truly devastating happens, like someone I know getting cancer or passing away. I'm not super 'oh my god, happy' all the time, but I feel pretty good consistently.

Regarding my daily life and functioning, I don't struggle with sleep at all; I go right to sleep when I get tired. I'm also quite energetic and motivated, especially lately, really grinding to find more event planning work. I don't feel guilty about any decisions I've made in my life; I truly believe I've made good choices and always stick to my moral compass.

One of my main ways to manage stress and keep my energy up is by going to the gym and working out. I notice that if I skip a couple of days, I do feel a little more tired than normal, but working out helps me feel good and keeps my energy levels going."

summary:
Today, I'm doing good, and I generally try to stay on a center line with my emotions, not usually too happy, but content. However, there are certainly aspects of my emotional life and daily functioning that present challenges.

Sometimes, I find it hard to express my own thoughts, which ties into me being a shy person. When I'm feeling tense, I'll even turn on a fish tank screensaver to relax, or just stare at a real one. I also carry a specific feeling of guilt about not taking better care of my pet bird; I let it out into the wild, and now I sort of wish it was closer to me, and that I had planned a better future for it.

A significant source of emotional pain and even a little spiritual anxiety about my future comes from my relationships, particularly with my grown kids. While our relationship is good, it can be difficult and painstaking at times. I have this tendency where I'd rather give my time to other people than take time for myself, even when I need it. This self-neglect has really caused me a lot of emotional pain.

Making decisions can also be hard. I remember a really tough decision about a job opportunity, where I had to weigh the financial gain and knowledge against the emotional pain of leaving my family. I wish I could be more decisive about things in general.

My sleep is usually pretty good, and I handle it well. But when I don't sleep well, I can become irritable, and there are also times when I'm just unhappy. I try to get as much sleep as I need to avoid that.

While I haven't been diagnosed with depression, these experiences of emotional pain, guilt, difficulty expressing myself, and the struggle with prioritizing my own needs over others are things I navigate regularly. I also wish I had the same ability for meeting more people, as I'm quite shy. Transitioning back to civilian life after the military wasn't easy either, and it took a lot of family and community help to adjust.

summary:
Here’s a summary of my experience with depression:

Lately, I've been feeling pretty down on myself and down on life. It’s not a new feeling for me; I was first diagnosed with depression in my early twenties. Back then, it was triggered by a difficult breakup, and I didn't even recognize it as depression, just a profound upset. I sought help and was prescribed Xanax, which helped me get through that period. Since then, I've had bouts of depression throughout the years, often for various reasons, but usually tied to relationships. The most recent time I was formally diagnosed and put on medication was about two years ago, and I'm still on those meds, though I don't go to therapy now because I don't have insurance.

My current struggles are heavily influenced by my pending separation and divorce. My relationship with my husband isn't good, and we're still together due to financial reasons, which isn't ideal. This financial instability is a huge source of stress. I'm unemployed, and I don't know what I want to do with my life. I never finished college, and I regret that extremely. I feel like I need to get a job and be able to take care of myself so I can divorce and move on. I believe that having no money is incredibly depressing; it feels like you can't even try to fix anything because you lack the means. I also worry a lot about my daughters, who are teenagers now. I fear I made many mistakes with their guidance and in their early childhood, and I worry it's too late to correct them.

Sleep is a major challenge for me. It's not easy to get a good night's sleep. Sometimes it's hard to fall asleep because there's 'too much on my mind,' and I feel like I haven't accomplished enough during the day. Most of the time, I wake up in the middle of the night, usually to go to the bathroom, and then I can't get back to sleep easily. I'm kind of used to feeling tired all the time, and I just push through the day. When I can, I cope by staying home, curling up in bed to read, take a nap, or watch TV – just kind of 'vegetating.'

I find it hard to remember the good times; I tend to remember the bad ones. When asked about the last time I felt really happy, I could only think of when my children were born, and even then, I just said it was 'nice to have them.' Recently, I did enjoy going to a friend's house to make vision boards with other girlfriends, which was fun.

A significant past event that still affects me is a betrayal by one of my best friends about eight years ago, related to a real estate deal. It was devastating, and even though I try to ignore it and put it out of my head, the vivid bad memory still comes up, especially now that our daughters are becoming closer friends.

Overall, I feel a sense of deep regret about past choices, particularly not finishing college and not securing my financial future. I wish I had figured things out earlier in life and been less of a 'wimp,' as I see it. I'm not proud of much in my life, beyond my daughters and being a vegetarian, which reflects my caring nature towards others.

Hi, I'm Ellie. When it comes to my mental health, particularly regarding things like depression, I'd say my experience is quite positive.

For my mood and emotional state, I'm genuinely a very happy person. In fact, I'm always happy. My day is usually going "really happy and good," and I find happiness in simple things, like talking to my boyfriend, going out and doing something, or just finishing work for the day. Right now, I'm on spring break, and I'm really happy about that. I don't really feel guilty about many things, and I don't dwell on negative experiences; nothing has bothered me so much that I have to actively try not to think about it. I also don't have any regrets, believing that whatever happens is meant to play out that way.

In terms of my daily functioning, I sleep really well as long as I get enough hours. My motivation seems good; I'm studying psychology and have goals like studying and exercising more, though I haven't traveled in about five years, which is just because I haven't been able to. Socially, I consider myself outgoing once you get to know me, and I believe most people like me. I do keep in touch with my dad and stepmom, though not super frequently, as they live in Oregon and I'm pretty much the only family member out here.

As for specific symptoms or coping strategies related to depression, I don't really experience typical symptoms like sadness or hopelessness. When I need to relax, I usually go to sleep, eat something good, or watch a good movie, especially foreign martial arts films. My general outlook is to not worry too much about small things, as I believe they are often insignificant in the long run and I won't think about them six months from now.

Overall, I'd say my mental health is good. I'm proud of being able to take care of and support myself without having to go back home.

summary:
I'm actually feeling pretty good today, which is mostly because I slept for about 85% of yesterday. Usually, I'm constantly busy with work, school, and my social life, so having a day where I could just sleep was a relief. Even after all that sleep, I still feel kind of tired, and I've got other stuff going on. It's weird, I can fall asleep almost anywhere – I even nearly fell asleep standing up the other day, which would have been strange! I do a lot, so I don't get as much sleep as I'd like, but I figure I can sleep when I'm dead, you know?

When it comes to how I deal with things, playing poker is a big one for me. It's actually kind of like therapy. When I'm playing, I can just focus on the game and not think about anything stressful, or about being depressed, or about stuff that's happened in the past. It's really relieving, almost like a drug in that sense, because it helps me forget. The only downside is that poker itself can be really stressful too, so it's a bit of a catch-22. Besides poker, playing basketball, going to the beach when it's hot, and hanging out with my friends also help me deal with things and feel good.

A lot of my emotional struggles are tied to relationships. The hardest decision I've ever had to make was choosing to stay away from an ex-girlfriend. I'm still in love with her and miss her, but I knew that relationship wasn't healthy, and staying together would have just led to more stress and irritability. It was, and still is, a really hard decision not to be with someone I loved and who loved me. I also wish I had never met my last girlfriend, because we were together for a few years, and the breakup was incredibly hard.

Looking back, I also regret getting involved with the wrong group of people when I was younger. I was doing really well then, working towards my dream of being a filmmaker, and I had my own car and apartment. But after getting involved with them, everything kind of tumbled downhill, and I lost my car, my job, and my apartment. I just wish I'd never met those people or that kind of girl, because my life would probably be a lot different now.

I also have this ongoing internal struggle where I feel like I need to be in a relationship with a girl all the time, and I wish I didn't. I feel like I'm always thinking about sexual stuff and needing to be with girls, almost like an addiction. I honestly believe that if I didn't concentrate so much on that, I could get a lot more done in my life. It's something I'm actively working on.

Despite everything, I believe that everything happens for a reason, and I try to learn from my mistakes and just keep going.

summary:
I've been doing okay today. I'm from LA, and while I like the weather, sports, and entertainment, it can feel a bit samey since I've lived here all my life. I studied computer programming back in the 70s, but I never really pursued it to the degree I wanted to, as I took a different turn in my life.

When it comes to my emotional state, I've found that I tend to feel a little bit depressed. This feeling largely stems from not having a strong support system or anyone I can truly count on or confide in. My only remaining family is my uncle in Florida, and while we communicate regularly, our conversations are quite shallow. We don't get into anything deep because he has his own problems, and I don't feel like I can really open up to him. This lack of deep connection definitely contributes to my mood.

To relax and cope, I usually watch music or TV. I make a conscious effort to avoid stressful situations to stay calm. I also find comfort in talking to my friends; being around them in a safe, comfortable environment allows me to just dialogue and focus on the moment, rather than worrying about my own problems.

It's not that I'm always feeling down, though. I actually felt really happy about a month ago when I helped out a lady at a trade show in Anaheim. It was a great experience – we had nice meals, there were lots of samples, and it was a chance to get away from LA. I met some interesting, outgoing people and enjoyed socializing with the colleagues I was with. That situation really lifted my spirits.

Looking back, I also carry some regrets, particularly about financial decisions I made years ago. I let other people's opinions and advice influence me, going against my own conservative nature, and it didn't turn out well. That's an area of my life that I still regret.

summary:
While I haven't been diagnosed with depression, I can share some of the emotional challenges and daily struggles I've experienced.

My emotional state has been deeply affected by significant losses. I still carry a lot of guilt about how things ended before my mom passed away. Even though people have told me not to feel bad because she wasn't really there for me growing up, I wish I could have been there more for her before she died. Her passing was incredibly difficult; I felt kind of robbed. I grew up with my grandparents, and after so many years without a real mom and dad, for her to leave me at 18 felt nerve-racking. It was like, I didn't have her all those years, and now that I'm older, I don't even have her now. I've also experienced the pain of losing many friends to gang violence through elementary and high school, which was pretty tough.

These experiences have impacted my daily functioning. It's hard for me to get a good night's sleep; I didn't even sleep last night, which makes me groggy. Sometimes, if it weren't for my daughter, I probably would have still been in bed. Being a parent is the hardest job, but my daughter is my heart, my pride and joy, and she gives me the enthusiasm to go the extra mile. Providing for her motivates me to push through and make sure she has everything she needs.

In terms of coping, I've learned to control my temper and actively block out negativity. I don't let stuff get to me anymore, and I don't really remember the last time I had to control my temper because I try so hard to block out the negativity. I also used to let what other people thought bother me, but I don't anymore. To relax, I sometimes turn on a fishtank screensaver, or ideally, I like to sit at the beach, zone everyone else out, and rub my toes in the sand as the waves collapse against the rocks. My belief in God also keeps me strong.

Lately, I've been feeling very confident and positive, especially about being a good parent and going the extra mile. Today is my daughter's birthday, and I feel so happy that I brought her into this world. It's moments like when she tells me I'm her heart that make being a parent the best thing.

summary:
I've been asked to describe my experience with depression, but honestly, based on our conversation, I don't really identify with having experienced depression in the way you might be thinking. In fact, I tend to be a very positive person.

My mood and emotional state are generally characterized by a sense of being "alive." I feel all my senses are completely awoken, especially when I'm traveling and experiencing different cultures, foods, and smells. I consider myself a very gutsy person; when I feel passionate about something, I risk everything to go achieve it. I make decisions quickly, always going with my gut feeling about what will yield joy, even if there's only a small chance of success. I believe it's a waste of time and energy to consider choices that won't bring joy. I don't hold residual negativity, bitterness, or fear from past experiences. I feel blessed that I don't need to block traumatic events; I've been able to accept unfortunate things that have happened.

In terms of daily functioning, I have very high energy and don't need much sleep. I can literally fall asleep anywhere, even on a bumpy, unpaved road in Africa or on a short flight, which means I don't struggle with insomnia. I enjoy social interactions, having great meals with friends, laughing, and listening to music. My motivation is driven by passion and the pursuit of awe and wonderment.

Regarding specific symptoms or coping strategies, I mentioned a strong belief in self-healing. Even as a child, I'd tell myself the "good part" would help the "bad part," and I concentrated on healing after a severe car accident, which doctors found incredible. When annoyed, I try to be more patient and empathetic, which travel helps me cultivate by forcing me to understand other people's lives. I've also found that even "horrible situations," like being completely ripped off by a business partner who stole my entire life savings, have opened up great experiences for me, like living in Barcelona and Zurich and learning new languages. I see the positiveness in these situations and don't dwell on regrets.

I've faced significant challenges, such as my father being a "vegetable" in the hospital and having to make the decision to disconnect him from life support. While it was very hard, it didn't traumatize me in a way that affects my behavior or leaves me with hidden issues. My experience with a Scientologist trying to "audit" me while I was having a lupus flare-up was irritating due to his pompousness, but it didn't lead to any lasting negative emotional impact. Overall, I'm in pretty good spirits, even with physical issues like photosensitivity and skin flare-ups. My life philosophy is to live with passion and pursue what brings happiness, regardless of the risks.

summary:
Here's a summary of my experience with depression, from my perspective:

Lately, I've been feeling very "so-so," almost like I'm in a "one note land" with no extreme highs or lows. It's not a sudden change; over the past few years, I've progressively become more seclusive and reserved, not very outgoing at all.

Sleep has become a consistent issue for me. While I usually fall asleep easily, the problem is staying asleep. No matter if I go to bed at 10 PM or 4 AM, I'll be awake like clockwork by 7:30 or 8:00 AM at the latest, every single day. I can't remember the last time I slept past 8:30 AM. This was never a consistent problem before, but now it is. It definitely makes me more tired if I have things to do during the day, but I've gotten so used to it that it doesn't really change my mood anymore; it's just part of my everyday life.

I've also been diagnosed with anxiety. I even had a scary experience with breathing problems that sent me to the hospital, and it turned out to be a physical manifestation of my anxiety. When I'm feeling tense, I sometimes turn on a fish tank screensaver or watch lighthearted reality television, like Bravo shows. They're funny and don't require much attention, which helps me relax.

There's been some ongoing tension with my dad, especially since I visited over the holidays. We've argued about his girlfriend, and he expects me to make all the effort to build a relationship with her, which I find frustrating. Sometimes I wish I could just bite my tongue, but he says things that are untrue or designed to provoke me, and I just lose it.

Looking back, one of the hardest decisions I made was choosing my college. Moving to California and doing everything on my own felt like a natural progression at the time, but now I regret the college I chose. I didn't realize it was more of a transfer school and not a general college where I could get a bachelor's degree, which created more problems for me. If I could give my younger self advice, I'd tell myself to probably stay closer to home and explore other options instead of being completely invested in moving to California. I also wish I could erase the memory of seeing my grandmother's funeral; it's not something I want to have in my memory.

Despite these things, I do find happiness when I'm back home at my boyfriend's house with his family, especially over the New Year's holiday. When I'm there, it feels like a complete vacation. I don't have to worry about paying bills or what I have to do the next day; we just wake up, hang out, and enjoy the day.

summary:
Here is a summary of my experience with depression, from my perspective:

"I've been feeling really down lately, and it's been going on for the past few months now. It started gradually, but it's become pretty constant. It's more than just sadness; it's like a heavy, empty feeling inside. Sometimes I just feel numb, or completely overwhelmed by everything. There's this deep sense of hopelessness, like nothing will ever get better, and a lot of guilt for not being able to 'snap out of it' or for feeling like I'm letting people down. I've also noticed I'm much more irritable, with a really short fuse with my family and friends.

This has really impacted my daily life. I have so much trouble falling asleep, or I wake up multiple times during the night, which leaves me exhausted all day. My appetite has changed significantly; I've lost interest in food and have lost some weight. I have no energy for anything. Things I used to enjoy, like painting or going for walks, just feel like too much effort, and it's hard to even get out of bed in the morning. Even basic things like showering or getting dressed feel like monumental tasks. My concentration at work has plummeted, and my productivity has really dropped.

I've been isolating myself a lot. I cancel plans with friends because I just don't have the energy or desire to socialize, and I feel like a burden when I'm around people. I try to push myself to do things, but it rarely works. Most of the time, I just end up staying home, watching TV, or staring at the wall. Sometimes I just cry, but it doesn't really help much. I've tried listening to music or reading, but my mind just wanders.

I think it got worse after I lost my job a few months ago. That really knocked me down, and I haven't been able to bounce back. My family has noticed what's going on, and they're trying to be supportive, but I often just push them away, which I feel bad about. I haven't really talked to anyone about this deeply until now."

summary:
I've been feeling really down lately, like a heavy cloud is constantly over me. It's more than just sadness; it's a deep emptiness, a profound sense of hopelessness. I feel utterly drained, as if all my energy has been sucked out. On top of that, there's this pervasive guilt – I feel guilty for not being able to snap out of it, for letting down my family and friends.

My daily life has become a constant struggle. Just getting out of bed feels like climbing a mountain. I used to love cooking, but now even the thought of preparing a meal is exhausting. My appetite is completely gone, and I barely eat anything. Sleep is also a huge problem; either I can't fall asleep at all, or I sleep too much but never feel rested. I'm just constantly tired, no matter how much I sleep.

I've found myself isolating a lot. I cancel plans at the last minute and avoid calls because I just don't have the energy to pretend I'm okay. I also don't want to burden anyone with my problems, and even though my friends try to reach out, I tend to push them away.

This all started a few months ago, after I lost my job. That was a really big blow, and I haven't been able to recover from it; in fact, it just keeps getting worse. I try to distract myself by watching TV or endlessly scrolling on my phone, but it doesn't really help. It just numbs me for a little while, but the feeling always comes back.

My family is worried and has been trying to be supportive, but I just feel like a burden to them. I know deep down that I need help, but it's incredibly hard to even think about taking that step. This conversation is actually the first time I'm really talking about any of this.

summary:
I was diagnosed with depression back in 2004. What led me to seek help at that time was that my life had become so incredibly stressful that I felt I had to do something or end something, to be honest.

Lately, I've been feeling a little anxious. This is partly due to a recent move to a new apartment, which brought a lot of new expenses and stress. It was a whole stressful situation, even though I managed to get through it.

One of the most significant impacts of my depression is on my sleep. I simply don't get a good night's sleep, or any sleep at all, unless I take medication. If I don't take it, I'll be up all night, sometimes even for days. When I'm sleep-deprived, I become irritable and tired.

When it comes to my emotional state, it's hard for me to pinpoint when I last felt truly happy. I can experience happiness from some unexpected occurrence, or if things go right for a change and continue to go right, as opposed to things constantly going wrong. But then, I often go back to how I was feeling before. It's also difficult for me to think of anything I've done recently that I genuinely enjoyed. Even activities I like, like playing tennis, I haven't been able to do lately due to physical problems.

I've been in therapy since 2004, and I find it very useful. It serves as a good sounding board where I can express my concerns and discuss things that might be bothering me. Therapy, combined with medication, has brought about a lot of changes for me; I've become more focused and more hopeful. It's still a struggle, but it's been a good experience, which is why I continue to go. Outside of therapy and medication, I try to relax by listening to music, watching horror movies, and watching my fish tank. Playing tennis also helps me relax when I'm able to.

While I don't have a best friend, I pride myself on being an honest, generous person who enjoys helping others. Doing something for someone else that helps them out genuinely gives me pleasure.

summary:
When asked about my experience with depression, I should clarify that I haven't actually been diagnosed with it, and currently, I feel emotionally good, especially being on vacation from work. I recently had a really happy time going out of town with my husband, enjoying wine tasting and the beach.

However, I do have a significant and persistent issue with sleep. It's rare for me to sleep through the whole night, as I usually wake up a few times. I often have a hard time falling asleep, sometimes experience bad dreams, or need to get up. I can't remember the last time I slept an entire night without waking up at least once, and I often feel tired in the morning because of it. I'm definitely not a morning person.

In terms of daily life, I do feel a bit bad that I haven't been to the gym in a while, even though I enjoy working out and it helps me deal with stress and relax. Socially, I consider myself quite shy. I often feel uncomfortable and a bit out of place in social situations, and I'm not one to start conversations. This shyness means I don't have a large group of friends, and I wish I was more outgoing so I could connect with more people.

I also carry the memory of a very traumatic event from about 15 years ago, when I was at a club and a guy tried to choke me. I genuinely thought I was going to die. Although my friend intervened and we left, it was a terrifying experience that I still think about and wish I could erase from my mind.

Despite these challenges, I cope by reading and taking baths to relax. I also have a good relationship with my family and my husband, and I'm proud of my academic achievement in getting my degree from UCLA.

summary:
Okay, so I've been diagnosed with depression, but honestly, I don't really see myself as any more depressed than anyone else. I think everyone has their own breaking points.

Lately, I've been feeling like I have so much potential, like a wealth of gold right there in my grasp, but it's just out of reach. I know I'm capable of a lot, I just need that one connection to really see what I can do. It's a feeling of being stuck, almost like I let something small and meaningless stop me from going further in school, and I regret that "ignorance" now. I wish I could tell my younger self to just stop thinking about the past and do what needs to be done.

When it comes to my emotional state, I've seen a lot of pain in the world, a compilation of bad things that I wish I could just erase from my memory. It's a heavy burden. The hardest decision I ever had to make was to start loving again, which probably tells you something about how I was feeling for a while.

In terms of daily life, my sleep "comes," but when it doesn't, I'm just tired and yawning. My appetite is fine, I'm very good at controlling my hunger. Socially, things are a bit complicated. My family doesn't really talk much. With my wife, I'm not sure if she truly wants to be with me; she thinks I'm doing everything but I'm not, and I don't really understand why. I know my daughter loves me, but there's still a part of me that wonders if she really wants to be with me. I pay attention to how people say things, the tone in their voice, the belief in their eyes – it tells you what's really in their heart, not just what they say.

My daughter is my angel, my biggest pride. I love seeing her smile. I try my best to guard her from the kind of things I saw when I was younger, things no child or adult should ever have to witness. My old foster parents were a positive influence; they showed me that you can always strive to get better, no matter where you come from.

To relax, I meditate, work out, run, walk, write, and read. I try to stay positive, goal-oriented, and determined, and I'm very imaginative and creative. But despite all that, there's this persistent feeling of knowing what I'm capable of, but not quite being able to reach it.

summary:
Here's a summary of my experience with depression, from my perspective:

My current mood is absolutely marvelous, and I feel happy every day, grateful to be alive and able to breathe, see, walk, talk, and still pursue my passion for photography. It's a good thing to be in the present moment and to be alive.

However, I've faced some deeply challenging experiences that have brought on feelings of distress and even depression. The most immediate and ongoing struggle stems from the stroke I had in February 2012. Over a year later, I still have nerve damage in my hand and face, and it's been depressing that it hasn't gotten better as I'd hoped. The biggest source of my current depression is the long, drawn-out process of trying to get disability. It's almost two years since my stroke, and I won't even have a hearing until September 2013 just to find out if I qualify. This uncertainty has left my life feeling "up in the air." I've had to live off my savings, and now my daughter, who I put through college, is having to take care of me while she's still looking for a job. It's very depressing to think about all the years I've worked since I was 16, only to be in this position now, wondering what comes next. I'm praying for guidance to navigate this.

Beyond this, I've experienced other difficult emotions. I felt terrible and guilty after an argument with my daughter, realizing my words had hurt her, even if unintentionally. There's also a "bad night" from my past that changed my life, which I still feel bad about and regret not staying home. My divorce was also a devastating time; I was very hurt and felt I played a part in keeping the drama going because I was so upset about the breakup, especially wanting my child to be raised with her father. The stroke itself was incredibly traumatic and disturbing; being overwhelmed and not knowing what was happening to my body was a terrifying experience.

Despite these challenges, I actively work to manage my emotional state. I practice meditation twice a day, in the morning and at night, using resources from Oprah and Deepak Chopra to calm my body. My photography is also a huge source of solace; even when I was very ill after the stroke, being able to go out and take pictures was incredibly soothing to my soul. I'm proud of finding my creative side, as it's been a vital coping mechanism. I try not to dwell on regrets, believing it's better to focus on the present and move forward, as you can't change the past. My gratitude for simply being alive helps me keep perspective, viewing my physical challenges as minor compared to the bigger picture.

summary:
My experience with mental health, particularly what I understand as depression, is deeply rooted in my struggles with emotional control. I've had a significant lack of control over my emotions, which ultimately led to my incarceration and being sent to prison. This difficulty managing my feelings also resulted in a physical altercation with another inmate while I was incarcerated, which added more time to my sentence. That's a situation I truly regret and wish I had handled differently, as it cost me a lot more time away from home.

Emotionally, I often find myself feeling frustrated, especially in my relationships, like recently when I was arguing about a lack of communication. Beyond that, a profound aspect of my experience is a recurring thought that I wish I could completely erase certain memories from my mind. It's not just the traumatic ones – like various fights, shootouts, or times I was jumped or robbed – but also the good memories. It's as if I want to disconnect from all emotional experiences entirely. These past traumatic events truly inhibit me from exploring certain areas of life that I'm not comfortable with.

Guilt is a heavy burden for me. I feel immense guilt for hurting people emotionally, particularly some women in my past, and for putting my mother, close friends, and family through things they didn't have to endure.

My daily functioning and life have been significantly impacted by these challenges. The incarceration itself is a major consequence of my emotional struggles. While my relationship with my family used to be rocky, the experiences I've been through have actually brought us closer, and it's pretty decent now. My mother has been a strong positive influence; I admire her resilience through difficult economic hardships and how she raised me while finishing school and getting her masters. It's also relevant context that she battled mental health issues herself, which gives me some understanding.

summary:
Here's a summary of my experience, focusing on aspects that relate to my mental well-being:

When it comes to my mood, I'd say I'm generally "pretty okay," but it really depends on the situation. There are times when I can be quite irritable, especially when I'm tired. If I'm tired, I'm "not good to be around" and I find it hard to focus. For example, just two days ago, I got into an argument with my sister and ended up losing my temper, which is something I regret. I wish I could think more before I speak.

I also find myself dwelling on past negative experiences. I wish I could just erase the thought of meeting certain negative people from my memory. There's also a sense of regret about not contacting old friends from elementary school; we lost touch after I switched schools, and I'm thinking I should try to reach out to them in the future. I've had to actively teach myself to be more outgoing because it doesn't come naturally to me; I tend to hold back. Sometimes I feel really bad about social misunderstandings, like the time I couldn't hold an elevator door for someone and they started cursing me out – I felt terrible because I thought they believed I didn't try.

In terms of daily functioning, my sleep is usually fine; I can fall asleep within five minutes if I'm tired enough. I was really into computer science as a teenager and was good at it, but I'm not working on it as much anymore, just a little bit.

To cope with things, I try to get out in the sun, go to the beach, or read a book when I want to relax. I'm also consciously trying to manage my temper and push myself to be more outgoing. The last time I felt truly happy was about a week ago when I went to an art walk downtown – that was exciting.

summary:
While I haven't been diagnosed with any specific psychological condition, I can share aspects of my experience that might be relevant.

I often find myself feeling remorseful about things I've said or done in the past, especially in interpersonal reactions with friends or family. These thoughts can just hit me out of the blue, making me reflect, "Why did I say that? Why did I do that?" It's not necessarily guilt, but a strong sense of regret that comes up. I've certainly grown emotionally over time; I think in the past, my emotional IQ was quite low, almost "stuck on infant." This led to some difficult altercations, particularly with my mom, and hurting the ones closest to you really sticks with you. My relationship with my father was also never good, and that's something that's been a part of my life, though he's now in advanced Alzheimer's.

There are periods when I feel quite lethargic, like I'm just going through the motions. Getting up and starting the day with enthusiasm isn't always immediate; if it happens, it's a gradual process. I'm always thinking about my behavior and thought processes, striving to be more productive and efficient with my time, because I truly hate wasting time, money, or energy. I often regret not being more productive each day.

However, I generally sleep very well, getting a solid eight to ten hours each night. I also prioritize my relationships with friends and family, understanding they require time and energy, and I make sure to invest that. I find great satisfaction and an "endorphin high" from engaging in deep, informed conversations with smart, open-minded people. To relax, I swim, and sometimes I'll just turn on my fish tank screen saver. When I'm annoyed, I tend to swear to myself, but I'm generally pretty good at controlling my anger.

Looking back, I recognize that I was codependent ten or twenty years ago, and I've learned that seeking help is important. Managing the stress of everyday living has also been a long and difficult process for me.

You know, just be able to turn off the phone and turn off everything and just be with her doing other different things. Yeah. Mm-hmm. How are your best friends around you? Like an outgoing guy, you know, very social, but at the same time I'm reserved depending how I feel with people. I have to, you know, build trust or feel comfortable with them. Uh-huh. What are some things you wish you could change about yourself? Well, I'm changing a lot, you know, like my temper and different things, drinking things. I'm changing a lot of different things so I could get more different things done. Tell me about a time when someone made you feel really badly about yourself. Well, there's several, but mostly is when I'm coming from Mexico that they want to demean you even down there. It feels like silly because I went to a store, I was regularly dressed, and I was telling them I wanted to buy something, and then they said that I wasn't belong there. And as soon as they saw my credit card, they kind of changed perspective because they saw the Wells Fargo logo, they know it was American. But they thought it was like, you know, it felt ridiculous to me because you go to a place, you have the money, you ask for something because you have it, not just to kill their time. Just because they saw a logo of a card, that's how they, you know, it was ridiculous for me. I understand. Is there anything you regret? No. What advice would you give yourself 10 or 20 years ago? Basically, to stay more focused on different things, stay in school, and, you know, don't go, you know, try to control my temper and do different things. Because if I knew what I know now, back then, it would be different. Hmm. What are you most proud of in your life? Well, I did drop out, but I did go back to school and, you know, I did get my high school. And right now I'm in the process of doing other different things. So right now it's getting my high school, getting that together. And right now I'm working to another goal and trying to get, you know, my, either going back to school. So basically getting back to school and finishing the high school, the GED. That's so good to hear. Mm-hmm. Okay. I think I've asked everything I need to. Thanks for sharing your thoughts with me. Okay. You're welcome. Bye. Okay. Stop the recordings. Mm-hmm. I feel like that works like I thought it would.
summary:
Okay, so when it comes to my mental health, I haven't been diagnosed with depression, and I haven't really noticed anything out of the ordinary in my behavior or thoughts lately.

However, I can tell you about how I generally feel and cope. Sometimes, I do feel overwhelmed, like recently when I was bugged about a bill I had already handled. And when I'm just waking up, I can feel a bit angry or just generally not good, lacking energy. But even if I don't feel like it, I know I have to do things, so I just push myself to go through with it no matter how I feel. Lately, I've been feeling good, maybe a little restless, but I still just put myself to do what needs to be done. I don't really feel guilty about much, not that I can think of right off the top of my head.

My sleep is usually pretty easy; I just knock out in about 15 to 30 minutes. But sometimes, it's really hard for me to wake up, even with the alarm. My girlfriend often has to wake me up because I'm just so out.

I'm generally an outgoing person, I like to be around people and get to know them, but I can also be reserved depending on how comfortable I feel. I'm very social, but I need to build trust.

I've been actively working on changing a lot of things about myself, like my temper and even my drinking habits, so I can get more things done. I like to unwind by listening to music or playing sports. My ideal weekend is just relaxing with my girlfriend, either out somewhere nice or at home, but without any calls or interruptions – just turning everything off.

Looking back, I regret dropping out of school and not controlling my temper better. My parents, who always worked hard, have been a big positive influence, pushing me to get things done correctly. It's hard to stay focused on the right things in LA sometimes because of all the negative influences. I'm proud that I went back to school and got my high school diploma, and now I'm working towards new goals, like learning graphic design and eventually starting my own business. I've been trying to get my life together more recently. I also remember a difficult time when my brothers died, which isn't a pleasant memory for me to talk about.

What did you study at school? I studied communications actually. I was a journalism public relations major with a minor in sociology and now I'm studying business. What made you decide to do that? I just thought that you know there would be more opportunities for me with business as far as jobs and then I have a desire to go to graduate school so I just figured in the long run it would put me in a better position, give me more opportunities with the communications. It's a little limited and especially as you get older the fields of TV reporting and things like that are kind of become you know harder to obtain so I just thought I would go into something more realistic and you know but I like both fields. I really do. I like communicating, writing, reading, talking as you can tell and so we'll see. What's your dream job? A couple probably but I would say ultimately would be traveling like working as like a travel writer, going to different destinations, trying different foods out, writing about different people, cultures, learning and living you know about those different people and cultures living amongst the people there and being interactive with the children and stuff like that so I kind of hope to be able to do that one day but yes it would be something along those lines and then the fallback would be a counselor, social worker, something in that area. If I could encompass all three hopefully I can. I would like to do that. That's actually a hard question probably because I initially grew up very shy and I'm not so much shy as I am reserved now but not conservative but just reserved and you know when I go somewhere I'm checking everything, everybody else out and then once I become comfortable or acclimate to a situation then I'm like okay you know I warm up to the situation or the people but I'm also friendly. I can be very friendly and outgoing. I like to talk. You know I seem like a chatterbox but I'm not really so usually if I'm in a big space with a whole lot of people I don't like to be the center of attention. I can attach myself to one or two people and you know become friendly with them but overall I am an open friendly person. For me it could be something as simple as just unplugging everything, all electronics and just sitting for a few moments meditating, praying or reading a good spiritual scripture. If I'm able to I like to go for a good massage, maybe get a facial, you know things that will I kind of like the physical part of it. I like massages, things that really release tension. And if not then just like I said just sitting at home reading and praying or I like the beach. I love the beach so sometimes I drive and go sit by the beach. summary:
Here is a summary of my experience with depression:

It's like a heavy cloud has settled over me, a constant sadness that's there even when there's no clear reason for it. Alongside that, there's this profound sense of hopelessness, a feeling that things will never truly get better. A lot of guilt comes with it too, especially about not being able to 'snap out of it' or feeling like I'm burdening my family. Sometimes I get really irritable, snapping at people I care about, which just piles on more guilt. Other times, I just feel numb, like I'm going through the motions without really feeling anything at all.

This isn't a new feeling for me; I've had episodes like this on and off since my early twenties, but this current one has been consistent for about six months now. It often gets worse during stressful times, like after a big work project or a personal setback, like my breakup last year.

My daily life is significantly impacted. My sleep is a mess – either I can't fall asleep at all, or I'm sleeping 12-14 hours and still waking up exhausted. My appetite is all over the place; some days I barely eat, others I'm constantly craving comfort food, especially sweets, which has led to significant weight fluctuations. I've become very isolated, cancelling plans and avoiding calls because it feels like too much effort to pretend to be okay. Even being around friends feels draining.

Motivation is at zero. Getting out of bed feels like climbing a mountain, and things I used to love, like hiking or reading, just don't interest me anymore. Even simple tasks like showering or doing dishes feel monumental. It's really impacting my work performance; I miss deadlines and can't concentrate, and my boss has definitely noticed. I also experience a lot of fatigue, even after sleeping a lot, and sometimes physical aches like headaches or stomach issues without a clear medical cause.

When I try to cope, I often just curl up in bed and cry, or try to distract myself with TV, but that's more avoiding than coping. I've tried mindfulness apps, but it's hard to stick with them when I feel so low. My family is supportive, but I feel bad burdening them, and I tend to push my partner away even though they try to help. I haven't really opened up to friends about the depth of what I'm going through. I finally decided to seek help because it's affecting my job and relationships too much, and I'm just tired of feeling this way.

summary:
I'm generally doing well, and I'd say I'm a happy person. When asked how I'm doing, I usually say I'm fine, and I truly believe I'm basically happy all the time. I find a lot of satisfaction in making other people happy and being a "resource person" for my friends and even my former supervisors, offering encouragement and input on their projects. It makes me feel good when they appreciate my advice and follow up on it.

Regarding my emotional state, I don't really experience mental health struggles. Any tiredness I've felt has been due to physical conditions, like vitamin B and D deficiencies, not my mental state. I have no problem sleeping; I sleep very well.

My daily functioning is pretty good. I'm outgoing in terms of going places, eating alone, and meeting people, though I can be a bit shy when conversing back and forth with strangers. I enjoy traveling, exploring different cuisines, and visiting historical museums. To relax, I love going online and entering sweepstakes; I've been quite successful at winning contests since I was a kid.

The main area where I express some dissatisfaction is with my weight. I have what I call a "yo-yo weight problem," where I lose weight for summer and then put it back on by Christmas. I tend to binge eat, which I think is a "nervous disorder," and I wish I could stop it so I could fit into my beautiful clothes. This is one of my main regrets, not being able to keep the weight off.

I've also had to navigate some difficult situations, like the passing of my mother in 1999. That was the hardest decision I've ever had to make, putting her funeral together and dealing with her unorganized affairs. It was a challenging time, as my siblings and I had never faced death before. However, I learned from that experience and have since organized my own affairs, including writing my own obituary and setting up a living trust, so my children won't have to go through what I did.

Overall, I feel very fortunate. I've been married for 33 years, and my marriage is strong. I'm incredibly proud of my two sons, who are responsible and successful, and I recently became a grandmother, which is wonderful. I also cherish my long-standing friendships; I still have 15 of my best friends from elementary school, and we're all still in contact and healthy.

summary:
I've been dealing with a lot, and it often feels like I'm trying to hide my emotions, especially when I'm upset. I know it's not good to keep things in because they'll just come out eventually, often as yelling. That really bothers me because I was yelled at a lot as a child, and I feel bad when I do it to my own children, even when I'm really upset. I try so hard not to, but sometimes it just happens.

My mind is constantly racing; I have too many things running through it, especially on the weekends. I'm constantly worried about my older kids when they're out, even though I know they'll come home. This makes it really hard to fall asleep most nights. Sometimes I'm just so exhausted from not getting good sleep that I pass out, but it's still hard. I also find myself thinking about things that aren't even happening, and my mind just jumps from one point to another without me even realizing how I got there.

Lately, I've been feeling very stressed, especially with my son dealing with legal issues and being incarcerated. It's been incredibly hard, and I've noticed I'm much shorter, moodier, and more irritable than usual because of it.

I do have ways I try to cope. When I feel too intense, I'll even turn on a fish tank screen saver – it's the best I've got! I also find relaxation in designing jewelry and beading. Therapy has been a really important part of my life; it was an intricate part of my week and really helped me cope. Unfortunately, I lost my therapist about two or three months ago because the program lost funding, and I'm in the process of finding a new one.

My OBGYN actually suggested I see a psychiatrist about three years ago, so this isn't a new struggle for me. There are specific things that really get to me, like repeated arguments with my husband about cheating. I'm so tired of that topic, and it just irritates me and often leads to yelling. I also remember feeling super guilty and obligated when I had to make a difficult decision about a past pregnancy.

Overall, it's a constant battle with my thoughts and emotions, impacting my sleep and how I interact with my family, especially my children.

summary:
My experience with depression feels quite heavy and pervasive. It's hard for me to pinpoint when I last felt truly happy; the most recent time I can recall was actually in a dream a few days ago, but even that memory is hazy. I don't really experience much joy from things like comedies or funny movies anymore.

My daily life is pretty limited. I don't do too much – mostly just go to the library or the park. I'm currently looking for a job, which adds to the stress. Getting a good night's sleep is hit-or-miss; it's often off and on, and I frequently feel tired. I haven't traveled for a while, mostly due to money.

Socially, I'm quite isolated. I don't have any best friends, and my relationship with my family is very distant; we only talk a couple of times a year. I tend to keep to myself.

Emotionally, I sometimes struggle with anger, wishing I could just ignore people instead of getting upset. I also carry some guilt, particularly about a career choice I made years ago. It's hard for me to remember times when I've felt valued by others, and I can't think of anything specific I regret, though I feel like there's probably a list somewhere.

To relax, I usually walk around my neighborhood or listen to music. These are simple things, but they're what I turn to. Overall, there's a sense of things being "not too much" or "not for a while" in my life, whether it's travel, engaging activities, or even just feeling truly happy.

And then finally I got to the point where I said I either have to shut up or do it. So that's that was one of my prouder experiences. OK, thank you. Bye. Thank you.
summary:
I'm feeling good today, positive and energetic, but my mood can really fluctuate. Just yesterday, I didn't feel so good; the cloudy weather made me just piddle about and waste a lot of time, not feeling up to doing things like working in my butterfly garden.

A big challenge for me is managing my emotions, especially at home. I tend to have outbursts every once in a while when things get too chaotic and I'm feeling very underappreciated. My husband doesn't always appreciate it, sometimes getting mad at me for being mad, which just escalates things. I've had moments, especially when I'm having a very tense day and things haven't gone right, where the pressure just builds up. Like that one time in the kitchen while making dinner, I got so frustrated that I actually took a pot and just banged it against the stove really hard to get people to pay attention, and I actually made a dent in my stove that's still there. I'm definitely more tense when I'm at home than when I'm camping, for example. I'm trying to become calmer and more patient, as I think my patience is what I need to work on the most.

Sleep has always been an issue for me; I've been an insomniac my whole life. I remember as a child watching the stars go across my bedroom window, and I haven't slept well for a long time. I've found that if I exercise and do something intellectually during the day, I have to be physically tired and intellectually tired to sleep well, which isn't always easy to achieve. A lot of times I stay awake reading until midnight, and even then, I'll often wake up at three again. I just got a new mattress, but that hasn't really helped me sleep.

Beyond that, I struggle with procrastination. I start many creative projects with a lot of enthusiasm, get almost finished, and then just completely lose interest. Sometimes I even think it's because I'm afraid to finish them, which sounds a little strange, but it's something I'm actively working on right now.

When I do have an outburst, my coping strategy is usually to isolate myself for a little bit. After that, I can come back more relaxed and deal with the situation calmly. It's very hard sometimes, but I've learned to stop, get myself out of there, take some deep breaths, and really try to figure out what I'm feeling, why I'm being angry or tense, so I can verbalize it. I also try to meditate, sit quietly, read, or walk my dog to relax. I even have an actual fish tank at my house that I find very calming.

Looking back, my childhood probably plays a role in how I parent and how I manage things at home. My mother kind of disconnected after my dad died when I was young, so I basically raised myself and didn't have a very warm or loving relationship or typical parenting skills. I know what not to do, but it's still very difficult sometimes. I'm not the typical warm, fuzzy, perfect mother, but I believe I'm a very good one, just more creative.

While I haven't been diagnosed with depression, these are some of the challenges I face in my daily life and emotional well-being.

summary:
Here's a summary of my experience with depression, from my perspective:

Sometimes, when things don't go my way, I can get depressed or upset. I recall a time I was just irritated, not angry, when I was told to quiet down and I just wanted to relax. My biggest struggle, the one that truly plagues me in my dreams and thoughts, is the memory of my mother's illness and death. She was sick with COPD, which turned into lung cancer, and I chose not to tell her how much her condition had worsened so she wouldn't be fearful. Sitting there, knowing the truth while letting her believe everything was okay, was incredibly difficult. Watching her health decline for three years and seeing her dependent on oxygen is something I wish I could erase, as if it never happened. Those thoughts and nightmares about her still come up and make me feel bad.

Beyond that profound grief, I also find myself getting frustrated when things don't pan out, like with financial problems or when I don't get jobs I'm qualified for and feel I'm not getting a fair chance. There was also a time I felt really bad when a good friend told me a recording I thought was my best work was horrible, and I couldn't understand how anyone could feel that way.

Despite these challenges, I generally sleep well, though those nightmares about my mother do sometimes wake me up, but I usually go back to sleep. I'm actively working on my goal to always look at the bright side of everything, no matter how bad things get, and to not complain about negative things. It's been very difficult, but I feel it's beginning to get a little easier. I try to be grateful for being alive and focus on my own objectives, making a conscious effort not to dwell on the negative things in my memory.

My girlfriend is a very good positive influence on me. When I'm stressed, listening to music and sitting with her calms me down. She's been trying to help me not be angry or negative and to be a more nurturing person, and I'm committed to improving because of her. For instance, I've been handling my financial problems well, partly because she told me I needed to address them. I don't often feel guilty, but if I get angry and shouldn't be, especially with my girlfriend, I do feel guilty because I never want to be short or use vulgar language around her. Today, I woke up feeling good, with a lot of goals, and achieving each one gives me a sense of accomplishment and happiness.
