summary:
Even though I haven't been diagnosed with depression and usually consider myself a happy, outgoing person who doesn't let things get me down, I've been experiencing some things lately that affect my energy and focus. I'm generally very social and enjoy being around people, and I don't typically feel guilty or have many regrets. I also usually find enjoyment in most things I do.

However, I've been feeling quite tired lately, which makes it harder for me to focus and concentrate. It just takes me longer to get things done because I don't have my usual energy. For example, I haven't been exercising as much as I normally would, like my half-hour walks, because I'm just not as motivated when the weather is dreary.

This tiredness seems to be a combination of factors. We've had a lot of gray days here in Los Angeles, especially near the ocean where I live, so I'm not getting enough sun, which I believe impacts my serotonin levels. My sleep is also an issue; I need eight hours, but I'm only getting around six. This is largely because my upstairs neighbors often take showers or do laundry late at night, sometimes around midnight, and the pipes running through my bedroom wall sound like "Niagara Falls." I also tend to wake up once or twice around 2 or 3 AM. On top of that, I suspect my thyroid might be acting up, and I have some vitamin deficiencies that could be contributing to my low energy.

While I have various ways to relax, like reading, watching shows, listening to music, or calling friends, these ongoing issues with my sleep, the weather, and my physical health are definitely impacting my energy and ability to concentrate right now.

summary:
Here’s a summary of my experience with depression, in my own words:

I've been feeling unwell for a long time; it's pretty much the same now as it always has been. There’s a general sense of "not feeling well" that just persists.

One of the biggest issues for me is sleep. I just can't sleep, and I never really get good rest. I wish I could sleep more to clear my mind, which often feels foggy or preoccupied. This lack of sleep definitely affects my daily life. For example, I don't go out at all socially. It's just not easy for me.

I spend a huge amount of time on my music, sometimes 12 hours a day, preparing and performing. It's incredibly demanding, especially with things like my Julliard audition, where you're judged by the top people in your field. Even though I work so hard, I always feel like there's "something more" I could be doing, like I'm not doing enough. This pressure is constant. Singing at the Metropolitan Opera, for instance, has always been very hard for me.

I can also get quite irritable. Just the other day, a guy cut me off while driving, and I got really angry. I also notice the "selfishness of people," which can be frustrating.

Music is really the only thing I truly enjoy. It's my passion. When I need to find some comfort or peace, I sometimes take a walk, or I'll put on a screen with a Hawaii scene – it's not the real thing, but it's the best I have to find some comfort. I've also found some peace learning to navigate.

A major decision for me was choosing my career over marrying my fiancée, which was incredibly difficult. I feel a lot of pressure to be where I want to be and who I want to be, and I'm constantly working harder to achieve that, always pushing forward. Despite these efforts, I haven't formally sought help for how I'm feeling, even though these problems have been consistent. I just feel like I have so much to do.

summary:
Here is a summary of my experience with depression, from my perspective:

I often find myself feeling "down" or "crappy," and sometimes even "alienated." When asked how I truly feel, the word that comes to mind is "hell." It's hard for me to pinpoint the last time I felt truly happy; I can't recall it. The closest I've come recently was learning to surf, which was "very chill."

Sleep is a constant struggle for me. I never sleep well, and it's been this way for as long as I can remember, perhaps even since I started school. I really wish I could sleep more, as I feel it would help me clear my mind.

I live with a persistent sense of pressure and the belief that I can always do more. Even if I spend 12 hours a day working on things, especially music, I always feel there's something more I *could* be doing. This drives me to work harder and take the lead, constantly pushing myself to be where and who I want to be. It feels like I have so much to do to reach my goals.

When I do feel down, I sometimes turn to my creative work, like my script, or I'll take a walk to try and feel okay. But mostly, my coping mechanism seems to be working even harder.

Socially, I find people in LA to be selfish. They do "crazy acts" but don't really "do anything" here. My last memorable interaction was a road rage incident three days ago, which left me feeling "pissed off."

There have been significant stressors in my life. My Julliard grad piece or audition was incredibly stressful and "crappy." It felt like being scrutinized by the most influential people in my field. Another major decision was choosing to pursue my career over marrying my fiancée. I also feel a constant self-criticism, believing I could always prepare and work much harder for things like interviews. I'm not sure what makes me feel bad sometimes, but I know I want to improve myself, like gaining muscle and "being more deeply."

summary:
Here is a summary of my experience with depression:

I'm Ellie, and I'm currently feeling okay, but lately, I've been feeling grumpy, irritable, down, and mixed with anger. This is mostly because of everything I'm going through with my soon-to-be ex-husband, especially finding out he's still dating the woman he cheated on me with. That made me feel really angry and hurt.

I was diagnosed with depression ten years ago, right after my son was born. At that time, I felt like I couldn't cope with life at all; I was so down and felt like I couldn't do anything. My sleep is still not good; I wake up a lot at night, and I don't know why, which is frustrating because if I knew, I could try to change it. When I don't sleep well, I'm even more grumpy and irritable.

When I'm feeling these emotions, I tend to keep them inside. I don't really have another way to deal with them. I've tried talk therapy in the past, but it didn't help; some therapists just sat and stared, and others gave advice that wasn't helpful. So now, I only go for medication management.

Being a parent is difficult, even though I love my son. The hardest part is guiding him emotionally, especially when I feel like I don't have all the answers. I'm also quite reserved and shy. When I'm tense, I sometimes put on a fish tank screensaver to relax, and I also like to listen to 80s music. My temper can be an issue, especially with my ex-husband or other adults, though I can control it with my son.

My family situation is complicated; my parents are gone, and I don't speak to my siblings. I regret not talking to my dad before he died and settling our differences. Ending my marriage was the hardest decision I've ever made, but I had to because of the cheating. I wish I hadn't given my life over to one person like I did with my husband. I also wish I wasn't sad and that I was more confident.

Despite all this, my son is the best thing about being a parent and what I'm most proud of. Playing with him is when I feel truly happy, as I can forget all the other "crap" in my life. I also find support and relaxation with my two good girlfriends. One of them is particularly positive and always looks on the bright side, which helps me a lot. Recently, a movie night with a friend was a relaxed and fun evening, which I really enjoyed.

summary:
My experience with depression has been a long one. I was diagnosed about ten years ago, right after my son was born. At that time, I felt like I couldn't cope with life at all; I was so down and truly felt like I couldn't do anything.

Currently, I've been feeling grumpy, irritable, and down, often mixed with anger. This is largely because of everything I'm going through with my soon-to-be ex-husband, especially after he told me he's still dating the woman he cheated on me with. That news made me feel really angry and deeply hurt. When these strong emotions arise, I tend to keep them inside, feeling there's nothing else to do but deal with it. I wish I wasn't sad and that I was more confident.

My daily functioning is definitely impacted. I don't get a good night's sleep; it's not easy, and I wake up a lot during the night. When I don't sleep well, I'm even more grumpy and irritable. While I love being a parent, I find it difficult, particularly guiding my son emotionally, as I often feel like I don't have all the answers. I'm a stay-at-home mom now. I've also been described as more shy and reserved, and I don't have contact with my siblings or my father before he passed, which suggests a lack of traditional family support.

To cope, I listen to music, especially 80s music, to relax. Sometimes, when I'm feeling tense, I even turn on a fish tank screensaver. I'm currently on medication management for my depression, but I don't do talk therapy anymore. I've tried therapists in the past, but I found them unhelpful – some just sat and stared, and others gave advice that I felt wasn't good or on point.

Despite the challenges, there are moments of true happiness. Just this morning, playing with my son made me really happy; I could forget all the other 'crap' in my life. He's what I'm most proud of. I also have two really good girlfriends who have been positive influences in my life; we can commiserate, and their positive outlook helps me a lot. Recently, I enjoyed a relaxed, fun movie night with a friend. Looking back, I regret giving my life over to one particular person, which is what I did with my ex-husband. Ending my marriage was the hardest decision I've ever made, but it was necessary because of his cheating.

summary:
My experience with feeling down is very much tied to my current life circumstances, especially my health. I haven't been officially diagnosed with depression, but doctors have considered it, and I've even tried depression drugs before, though they didn't help with my main issue, which is sleep.

My mood is often "down," a lot of times, actually. I wouldn't say it's unreasonable, though, considering how "strange" my life is right now and the difficulties I face due to my health. I do experience moments of happiness, like when I'm out with friends or discover a great new dish I enjoy. For example, I'm having fun staying with a friend after her surgery this week, even helping her find cupcake deals. These moments are enjoyable, but they seem to be situational. I'm not sure what kind of happiness you're looking for, but I do experience it.

The biggest impact on my daily life is my sleep. I sleep a lot, and I'm often in a deep sleep, but I never feel rested. It's a medical problem of mine – I constantly feel like I haven't slept for two days, and my sleep is just "crappy, physically pretty crappy." My sleeping problem hasn't been diagnosed, and I'm in the process of really working to get it diagnosed. There are only short periods during the day when I feel truly alert, alive, and rested. This chronic fatigue makes life really difficult.

Socially, I'm a very private person. I've always been this way, even before this difficult time in my life. I don't really tell people about my problems because I feel it can be a "killjoy" or make others uncomfortable. They might perceive that I have difficulties and feel like they should help, or even guilty, but they have busy lives. This tendency to keep things to myself can create a gap in my relationships, even though I'm very outgoing when I feel comfortable with people. I also tend to think a lot; I'm a deep thinker, and maybe I just have a lot of thoughts that don't seem appropriate to share.

Despite these challenges, I'm trying to cope. Aside from sleeping, I like relaxing things like going for a bike ride on the strand or just reading at home. Sometimes I can just lay there, and my mind might be doing things, but I'm kind of relaxing. When I'm feeling tense, I even turn on the fish tank screensaver. I didn't finish school when I was younger because of health problems, but I'm in school now, doing my general ed. I'm very proud that even though I have a lot of difficulties in my life, I'm making this commitment to go to school on my own, and I'm getting A's through everything.

summary:
Here's a summary of my experience with depression, as if I am the interviewee:

"While I haven't been officially diagnosed with depression, it's something doctors have often considered, especially in relation to my significant sleep problems. I sleep a lot, but I never feel rested; it's like I haven't slept for two days. This constant fatigue is a major medical issue for me, and it makes life really difficult. There are brief moments during some days where I feel truly alert and alive, but they are short-lived.

Emotionally, I would say I feel "down" quite often. My life is very strange right now, and my health isn't great, which I feel are very reasonable reasons to feel this way. It's not triggered by any one particular thing, but rather by the ongoing difficulties with my health.

I've been given depression drugs before, but they haven't helped with my sleep. I'm currently in the process of trying to get a proper diagnosis for my sleep issues.

Socially, I'm a very private person, and this tendency has become more pronounced with my current problems. I don't really tell people about my difficulties because I feel it can be a "killjoy," and I don't want to make others uncomfortable or feel guilty when they have their own busy lives. I feel it just creates a gap.

Despite all these challenges, I'm very proud of my perseverance. Even with all the difficulties I have, I've committed to going back to school on my own, and I'm getting A's. It's a significant achievement for me, especially when people might wonder why I'm even worried about school given everything else."

summary:
Here's a summary of my experience with depression, in my own words:

"Lately, I've been feeling very anxious and stressed out, and more than just somewhat sad – I've been truly sad. This isn't a new feeling for me; I've been dealing with depression or sadness for a very long time, maybe 30 or 35 years.

It really affects my daily life, especially my sleep. It's incredibly difficult to get a good night's rest. I struggle to fall asleep, and even when I do, I wake up frequently, often after just an hour or two. I looked it up, and apparently, it's common for people my age, but it leaves me feeling tired, depressed, and not well-rested. Overall, I just don't feel right.

A big part of what's triggering me right now is stress. I'm not working, and there are a lot of pressures. It feels like things just aren't going right, and I'm constantly getting bad news. Things aren't going my way, and it's tough to find a good job these days. This current situation really adds to my sadness, and I feel unprepared for the future.

I'm very hard on myself, constantly beating myself up. It happens every day. For example, I procrastinated on my car registration, and now it won't smog, costing me money and stress. I think about past mistakes, like not keeping a job, or things in my marriage 20 years ago, wishing I had been more mindful or handled situations differently. I even regret instances where I wasn't an attentive father, always wanting to be the best I can be.

Socially, I don't have a best friend, and I'm not very close with my daughter or my sister, though I am close with my son. My kids are doing very well, and seeing my son happy at his wedding last month was the last time I felt truly happy. It's a relief knowing he turned out to be a better person than me.

I've been in therapy for a long time, seeking help to improve my life and be the best person I can be. Certain therapists have been a positive influence, helping me with being mindful and less hard on myself. Sometimes I think therapy is useful, sometimes I don't; I haven't noticed much change. When I feel tense, I sometimes turn on a fish tank screen saver – it's not Hawaii, but it's what I've got. I also try to meditate, though it's not easy. My temper can be an issue; I'm not great at controlling it, especially in work situations, even if I don't get angry very often.

Ultimately, I wish I could be more content and happier. I really need to give myself a break and be easier on myself, instead of constantly dwelling on how I'm unprepared or how things aren't going my way."

summary:
Here's a summary of my experience with depression, in my own words:

Lately, I've been feeling very anxious and stressed out, and more than just somewhat sad – I've been sad a lot. It makes me feel like I don't feel right; I'm tired, depressed, and never really well-rested.

One of the biggest challenges for me is getting a good night's sleep. It's really difficult for me to fall asleep, and even when I do, I wake up a lot, often after just an hour or two. I've looked it up, and it seems like it might be related to my age, but it still leaves me feeling exhausted.

My current situation is a major source of stress. I'm not working right now, and I feel a lot of pressure. It seems like things just aren't going right; I'm getting a lot of bad news, and things aren't going my way lately, or even always. Finding a good job these days is tough. This contributes to a constant feeling of being unprepared for the future.

I'm very hard on myself, constantly thinking back to situations where I don't believe I handled myself properly. This happens every day. For example, I beat myself up over procrastinating on my car registration, which ended up costing a lot and still didn't pass smog. I also regret not keeping my last job and feel the pressure to find a new one. I think back to instances where I wasn't an attentive father, always wanting to be the best I can be, and it's hard when I feel I fall short. Even seeing my son happy and successful at his wedding made me happy, but I also felt he turned out to be a better person than me.

I've been dealing with this sadness, or depression, for a very long time – I'd say 30 or 35 years, though I'm not sure if it was a formal diagnosis back then. I first sought help because I wanted to improve my life, be the best person I could be, and ultimately, be happy. I still go to therapy now, and sometimes it feels useful, but other times I'm not so sure. I haven't noticed much change, or very little, and after being in therapy for such a long time, it's hard to tell what changes are from therapy versus just myself. However, therapists have helped me with being more mindful and less hard on myself, which is something I really need to work on. I wish I could be more content and happier, and just give myself a break instead of constantly beating myself up.

When I'm feeling tense, I sometimes turn on a fish tank screen saver to relax, and I try to meditate, though it's not easy. My temper can be an issue sometimes, though I don't get angry often. It has caused problems in work situations in the past, where I should have been more cool and calm. I recently argued about someone's excessive drinking and money, and it was frustrating because they couldn't listen easily.

Socially, I don't have a best friend. I'm close with my son, and somewhat with my daughter, but not very close with my sister. My family is really just my two kids. My own parents were abusive and threw me out, so I grew up in a foster home. I made a conscious effort to be a different parent, to not hit my kids, and I believe I've been a better parent than mine were. Being a parent is hard, especially with consistency and keeping emotions in check, but the unconditional love from my kids is truly the best part.

summary:
I've experienced depression in the past, specifically when I went through my divorce and when my mother passed away. That was a really difficult time for me. My symptoms included intense fatigue and just feeling tired all the time. No matter what I did, I couldn't get any enjoyment from anything. I felt a profound sense of emptiness, loneliness, and isolation, along with feelings of shock and trauma. It was very difficult to get through.

What helped me then was simply time; it just took time, a process to work its way through. I also went to therapy, and I found it incredibly useful. I loved my therapist because we would talk things out, and she gave me different perspectives while just listening to me. I stopped therapy because I got busy with life stuff, but I do feel it's useful and I need someone to talk to.

Currently, I'm feeling quite overwhelmed. I have a funeral to attend tomorrow, and I just found out from my doctor that I have some health issues. It's really hard, but I'm just putting one foot in front of the other and trying to get things done. Lately, getting a good night's sleep has been very difficult, primarily due to school, finals, and midterms coming up. I've been feeling annoyed, terrible, annoyed, and grouchy. To cope with all this, I pray a lot – that's the one thing that's keeping me grounded, along with going to church. I also find relaxation in riding my bike or going swimming.

summary:
Here’s my experience with depression, as I remember it:

I was diagnosed with depression during a really tough period in my life, specifically when I went through my divorce and my mother passed away. It was a very, very difficult time.

My symptoms were quite debilitating. I felt constant fatigue; I was just tired all the time, no matter what I did. The hardest part was that I couldn't get any enjoyment out of anything. There was just this overwhelming feeling of emptiness, loneliness, and isolation. It was a real shock and trauma for me.

During that period, and even sometimes now, it's been so difficult to get a good night's sleep, especially with school and finals. When I'm out of sleep, I become irritable, annoyed, and grouchy. I also have this side of me that just likes to withdraw and doesn't want to be out in the front, which often conflicts with another part of my personality.

To cope back then, it honestly just took time for the process to work its way through. I did go to therapy, and oh God, I loved my therapist. We would talk things out, and she’d give me a different perspective; she just listened to me. I stopped going because I just got busy with life stuff. But honestly, I still feel like I need somebody to talk to.

Currently, when I'm overwhelmed, like I am now, I cope by just putting one foot in front of the other and trying to get things done. My main grounding strategy is prayer; I just pray, Lord, I pray. And going to church is really keeping me grounded right now.

summary:
Here's a summary of my experience with depression:

I've been diagnosed with depression, and also a sleep disorder, both over 10 years ago. My emotional state often fluctuates; I can be happy at moments, but there are also times when I feel really, really sad. These don't really balance each other out. I often feel overstressed, sometimes defeated, insecure, and deeply hurt. I tend to put the weight of the world on my shoulders, and when I'm taking care of everyone else, I sometimes get lost in that transition. I'm also very hard on myself and don't give myself enough credit, which sometimes leads to me being taken advantage of because of how nice I am.

My daily functioning is significantly impacted, especially my sleep. I've been tossing and turning for years and can't remember the last time I got a good amount of sleep. Even with a new pillow, I'm still restless, and often I'll just lie there wanting to sleep, but it doesn't happen. Despite these poor sleep patterns, I still manage to get up and do what I have to do, as if I've had enough rest. While some days I feel fatigued and tired, usually I'm wide awake, active, overly bubbly, and a busy body.

Socially, I spend a lot of time alone, which isn't entirely by choice, but it has its good and bad aspects. I don't have a best friend, but if I did, I think they'd say I'm a loving, creative, funny, articulate, and blunt person, but also someone who is too hard on herself.

A lot of my emotional struggles stem from past experiences. I carry a lot on my shoulders and blame myself for things I can't control. For instance, I still feel immense guilt and blame myself for not being there to protect my younger brother when my physically abusive father beat him up years ago. That event caused me a nervous breakdown, and it still bothers the hell out of me to this day. Another deep hurt is remembering a time my mother's client didn't realize she had a daughter, only a son, making me feel like I didn't exist – that still bothers me to my core. I also feel bad about not being able to find my grandfather before he passed away, as he was asking about me. More recently, an argument with my ex-girlfriend about our past relationship still bothers us both, and we're trying to work through the hurt.

To cope, shopping is my number one go-to; it's very therapeutic and helps get my mind off feelings of hurt or insecurity. I also listen to music, go to the beach to take in the scenery and appreciate the small things, have a glass of wine, watch TV, have conversations, or pray. When I'm feeling tense, I even turn on a fish tank screensaver. While I was more quick-tempered in my 20s, I've grown to be more calm and centered now, though I still get upset and angry depending on the situation. A couple of days ago, I actually felt really happy – I was rested, caught up on shows, relaxed, and just had a rare day of peace and tranquility.

summary:
I've been living with depression for over ten years now, which was when I was first diagnosed. My emotional state is quite a mix; I can be happy and content at times, but there are also moments where I feel really, really sad. These feelings don't really balance each other out. I often feel overstressed, sometimes defeated, and insecure. It's like I put the weight of the world on my shoulders, taking care of everyone else, and sometimes I get lost in that transition. I tend to take on a lot, and I blame myself for things I know I can't control, which leads to a lot of guilt.

This guilt stems from several past experiences that still bother me deeply. For instance, I carry a lot of guilt about not being there to protect my younger brother when my physically abusive father beat him up badly. I felt like I had a nervous breakdown; I didn't handle that well, and to this day, I wish I had taken him to the hospital instead of just crying in the bathroom. That still bothers the hell out of me. I also feel guilty about not being there financially for my ex-girlfriend when she was in the hospital, as I couldn't get to Vegas. Another significant source of sadness and guilt is finding out years later that my great-grandfather, Frank, had passed away and had been asking about me, but I didn't know how to find him because family members withheld information. Even past comments from my mother, like her client not knowing she had a daughter, still hurt me to my core and bother me.

These emotional burdens significantly impact my daily life, particularly my sleep. For years, I've struggled with so much tossing and turning. Even with a new pillow, I'm still tossing and turning, and a lot of the time I just lie there wanting to go to sleep, but it doesn't happen. My sleep patterns are not great, and I don't know if it's my stress or what's going on. Despite this, I still manage to get up and do what I have to do. I'm usually active, completely wide awake, and outwardly bubbly and a busy body. While I spend a lot of time alone, it's often by choice.

To cope with these feelings, I have several strategies. Shopping is number one for me; it's very therapeutic and helps me escape feelings of hurt and insecurity. Once I get an idea for coordinating colors or something out of the norm, it just makes me happy. I also find relaxation in listening to music, going to the beach to take in the whole scenery, smell the ocean, and feel the sand between my feet. Sometimes, a glass of wine, watching TV, having a conversation, or praying helps too. I've noticed that as I've matured, I'm more calm and centered about things, and I don't get as angry as I used to, which is a better way to deal with things.

Overall, I'm a person who is too hard on myself, doesn't give myself enough credit, and sometimes gets taken advantage of because of how nice I am. While I cherish every day and am grateful to be able to work and do things for myself, those moments of peace and tranquility are kind of rare for me.

summary:
Lately, I haven't been feeling my best. I'm always nervous, depressed, and generally not happy. I've noticed changes in my behavior; I've been more jumpy and anxious, and I find myself fidgeting a lot.

Emotionally, happiness feels like a distant memory – the last time I truly felt happy was a long time ago, when my sister had her baby. I also carry a sense of guilt sometimes, especially about things I feel I have to do to get ahead of other people. There's a past bad relationship that still causes me a lot of problems because I just can't seem to forget it. I wish I wasn't so nervous all the time; it even affected me recently during a job interview, where I don't think I performed well because of it.

Sleep has become a real challenge for me. It's pretty hard to get a good night's sleep, and I usually need some sort of liquor to really fall asleep. When I don't sleep well, I feel like a groggy zombie the next day.

To cope, I often watch TV and drink to relax. Sometimes, when I'm feeling tense, I'll even put on the fish tape screen saver. Despite these struggles, I do have a pretty good relationship with my family, and my mom has been a particularly positive influence in my life. I also recently had a really fun time visiting my best friend in Philadelphia.

I haven't been diagnosed with depression or PTSD, but these feelings of nervousness and unhappiness have been present for a while now.

I've been feeling pretty depressed lately, kind of down. It's been a mild experience, and I'm glad to say I've been feeling a little better recently.

The main thing that seems to have triggered this was a family argument a few months back. That argument really hit me, and looking back, I probably wouldn't have yelled so much during it. I'm still feeling a bit tense sometimes because of it.

summary:
Here's my experience with depression, or what I call being "in a hole." It really hit me hard after my wife passed away three years ago. That was a truly awful time; I had to turn off her machines and watch her die right in front of me. She died from liver failure due to alcohol, and I still think about what I could have done differently, even though she didn't want help. That regret is always on my mind.

This loss, combined with losing my dad, older sister, older brother, and mother all within the last ten years, has been incredibly tough. It even made me sick a few times, landing me in the hospital.

When I was in that "hole," I felt a deep sense of helplessness. It felt like there was no light at the end of the tunnel, and I was just digging myself deeper. My mind was always racing, even when my body was resting. Sleep became a huge problem; I'm lucky if I get an hour of sleep a night because of the pain from my torn rotator cuff, but even without that, my mind just keeps going. I've been in that pattern for quite some time.

I did feel sorry for myself for a bit, but I knew I had to dig myself out. I've always been a pretty outgoing, happy-go-lucky kind of guy, able to talk to anyone. So, I decided to deal with it on my own. I don't go to therapy anymore, because I felt like they were telling me things that didn't make sense, like how long grieving should last. I believe you have to deal with your own problems, and everyone grieves differently.

To cope, I try to relax by turning on my fish tank screen saver – it's not Hawaii, but it's the best I've got. I also go fishing or play cards at the little casinos around here. I make sure to connect with my friends from all over the country; it's good to see them and know they're glad to see me. I've been proud of myself for getting away from drugs and alcohol, just leaving bad situations behind and going to new ones.

It's been a long process, taking it one day at a time, but things are definitely looking up now. I'm pulling myself out of that rut, and I feel good about it. I'm getting back to my old self, feeling happy all the time and dealing with things on my own terms.

summary:
Here’s a summary of my experience with depression, in my own words:

My experience with depression has been like falling into a deep hole, feeling a complete sense of helplessness. When you get into a hole like that, there really is no light at the end of the tunnel. It felt like I was just digging myself deeper, and it was incredibly hard to climb out.

The biggest trigger for this recent period was losing my wife three years ago. She died from liver shutdown due to alcohol, and I had to make the agonizing decision to turn off her machines and watch her pass right in front of me. That was incredibly tough. I kept thinking about what I could have done differently to help her, even though she didn't want any help. That regret and the constant thought of her have been on my mind every single day. It wasn't just her; I've had a lot of loss in the last ten years – my dad, older sister, older brother, my mother, and then my wife. All that loss has been really tough on me, even landing me in the hospital a few times.

When I was in that rut, my sleep was terrible. I don't sleep very well at all, maybe an hour a night, and that's been going on for quite some time. My body might be resting, but my mind just keeps thinking all the time. Part of it is also the pain from my torn rotator cuff; it's hard to get comfortable.

To cope, I've always been a happy-go-lucky kind of guy, and I'm pretty outgoing, able to talk to anyone. But when I was in that hole, I knew I had to dig myself out. I decided to take it one day at a time. I don't go to therapy anymore; I tried it a long time ago, about twenty years back, but I pretty much deal with my problems on my own now. I find ways to relax, like turning on my fish tank screen saver – it's not Hawaii, but it's what I've got. I also go fishing and play cards at the local casinos. Seeing my friends helps too; we went on a fishing trip recently, and I go to drag races to see friends from all over the country. I'm also proud of myself for getting away from drugs and alcohol, which was something I had to do by leaving a bad situation.

Things are looking up now. I'm getting out of that rut, pulling myself out. I still think of my wife every day, but I know I'm getting better. I feel happy all the time now, and my friends tell me I sound good. I'm just going with the flow and dealing with things myself.

summary:
Here's a summary of my experience with depression, in my own words:

Lately, I've been feeling pretty depressed, with a lot of mood swings and high anxiety. I live with a lot of isolation; I have no social life at all. I really struggle with communicating with women, I just don't know how to act around them, so I tend to stay to myself.

My sleep is a big problem. I have insomnia, and even though I'm on medication like Respidone and Trapezoid to help me sleep, I often only get about three hours of sleep a night. I'm up half the night, and I don't sleep well at all. Sometimes, I even see dead bodies, which is tied to my non-combat PTSD. I'm told I sleep a lot, and sometimes I over-medicate myself, so I worry I'm not a good person to be around.

My PTSD was diagnosed about a year ago, and it stems from trauma I experienced in the Navy. I had to recover a dead body in the Philippines, and I also witnessed a suicide in boot camp – a guy jumped three feet in front of me, and I saw his head explode like a pumpkin. That affected me greatly, and I still see it all the time. These experiences lead to cold sweats, nightmares, constant jitteriness, and always looking over my shoulder. I don't feel comfortable around people, and I have a hard time trusting anyone. I got tired of all those things – the nightmares, staying up, being jittery and antsy, and the cold sweats – that's what finally pushed me to seek help.

I'm on medication to help control my temper and mood swings, as I get aggravated really easily. Sometimes it just flares up, especially if someone gets in my face, but I try to prevent that from happening.

To relax, I listen to music, particularly relaxation music like chimes, a brook, or running water. Sometimes, when I'm tense, I put on a fish tank screensaver.

I've never really been happy in my life. I just live day to day, one day at a time. I've been through so many ups and downs and disappointments, and it's been hard. I've even slept in homeless shelters, garages, and closets. My family life was dysfunctional; we never even sat down for meals together, so I don't know much about family values. I also still feel guilty about a promise I couldn't keep to my brother about paying him back for his IRA.

Despite all this, I am making an effort to change. I'm getting out more now. Before, I'd always stay in my room, but now I push myself to go to movies or out for dinner by myself. My behavior has changed somewhat; I'm not staying in like I used to.

I go to group therapy every Wednesday for my PTSD, and it's been really useful. I'm learning things I didn't understand before. There are six of us in the group – Marines, Navy, Army, Air Force – and we share our experiences and help each other. We're even working on building relationships with our daughters, which is something many of us struggle with. My psychologist, Tim Morrissey, and my PTSD counselor have been positive influences. I also have a good friend who suffers from bipolar and PTSD, like me, and we're good for each other because we understand what the other is going through.

I'm 58 and lonely, looking for companionship, but I'm afraid to go out and ask someone because I don't know how to act or what to say, especially being on medication. I'm hoping to go to Philadelphia in September, which will be a big thing for me, getting out of California for a while.

summary:
Here's a summary of my experience with depression, in my own words:

Right now, I'm feeling pretty depressed, with a lot of mood swings and high anxiety. I also experience a lot of isolation; I have no social life and I don't really know how to act around women, so I tend to stay to myself. Honestly, I've never really been happy. My life has been a lot of ups and downs and disappointments, and it's been hard for me. I've even slept in homeless shelters, garages, and closets in the past.

My sleep is a constant struggle. I have insomnia and often see dead bodies in my mind, which are vivid memories from traumatic experiences in the Navy. Even with medication like Respidone and Trapezoid, which are supposed to help me sleep, I often only get about three hours of sleep and I'm up half the night. I don't sleep too well, and sometimes I even over-medicate myself. When I do sleep, I sleep a lot. I also get aggravated very easily, and I have mood swings and a personality disorder. Sometimes my temper just flares up, especially if someone gets in my face, but I try hard not to let it happen.

A big part of what I'm going through is non-combat PTSD, which I was diagnosed with a year ago. It stems from trauma I experienced in the Navy, like recovering a dead body in the Philippines and witnessing a suicide in boot camp. I see those dead bodies all the time, and it affected me greatly. These experiences cause me cold sweats, nightmares, insomnia, and make me feel jittery. I'm always looking over my shoulder, I don't feel comfortable around people, and I don't trust them.

I decided to seek help because I was just tired of all of it – the nightmares, staying up, the jitters, the cold sweats. I just got tired of not feeling comfortable. Now, I go to group therapy every Wednesday for my PTSD. It's been really useful. We're a group of veterans from different branches, and we share our experiences and help each other. It's helping me understand things I didn't before, and we're even working on building relationships with our daughters.

Lately, I've been making an effort to get out more. Before, I'd always stay in my room, but now I go to movies or out for dinner by myself. It's a small change, but it's a start. My psychologist, Tim Morrissey, my PTSD counselor, and a friend who also deals with bipolar and PTSD have been really positive influences in my life. My friend even tells me I'm a mess and in bad shape, worse off than I say I am.

I'm 58 years old, and I'm lonely. I'm looking for companionship, but I'm afraid to go out and ask women because I don't know how to act or what to say. Plus, being on medication, I worry about how that might affect things. Sometimes I feel like I'm not that good of a person to be around. Despite all this, I'm looking forward to a trip to Philadelphia in September; getting out of California for a while will be a big thing for me.

summary:
Lately, my feelings have been really up and down, and today, it's definitely been more of a down day. I'm a bit tired, partly because I had some bad dreams last night and my thoughts were just racing. When I don't get a good night's sleep, I end up waking up late, feeling groggy, and often sleep during the day. That's when I feel a little more depressed, a little more negative – not angry negative, but a sorrowful kind of negative.

I carry a lot of guilt about my failures, and honestly, when asked what I'm most proud of, I can't think of anything. I also feel a sense of inadequacy, especially when I think about my military service. I was upset because I never got to deploy, and I always felt like I wasn't a real soldier because I didn't have those combat stories or the camaraderie other soldiers shared. I'm still adjusting to civilian life, which is an ongoing process.

Socially, I feel like there's a push and pull. I see people who are appreciative and supportive of me, and they're really caring, but instead of letting myself fall into those good situations, I find myself pushing away. There's an uncertainty, and I feel like if I speak my thoughts, I'll be wrong, or it'll change everything, so I just don't say anything. It's frustrating because it's right there, but I'm not looking at it.

A few weeks ago, I was diagnosed with PTSD. I've noticed I can get snappy when I'm triggered, but I don't always know what the triggers are. To cope, I've started meditating again, which has been really helping. I also try to vent, turn things into jokes, or write. Therapy is highly useful; it helps me understand myself and my issues better. I also enjoy doing yoga and riding my bike.

A big part of why I sought help was because I was on a spiritual journey, and my mom didn't like it. Currently, the medication I'm on is really messing with my mood, and it's a whole big mix-up because I feel like I should be on something different. I need to be more assertive with my doctors about it, but I'm trying to find that balance of being assertive without being aggressive.

summary:
Here's a summary of my experience with depression, from my perspective:

Lately, my mood has been really up and down, and today, I'm definitely feeling pretty down. I woke up tired after some bad dreams and racing thoughts last night, which often leaves me groggy and sleeping during the day. When I don't sleep well, I tend to feel even more depressed and a "sorrow negative" kind of negative – not angry, just a low, heavy feeling.

I often feel a sense of guilt, especially about my failures. There's also this deep-seated feeling of inadequacy, particularly stemming from my time in the military. I never deployed or saw combat, and I always felt like less of a soldier because I didn't have those shared experiences or camaraderie that other soldiers had. It's hard to feel proud of anything in my life right now; when asked, my honest answer is "nothing."

Socially, I find myself in a push-and-pull situation with people who are genuinely appreciative and supportive. I feel like I'm pushing them away, even though I know it's not a bad situation. There's an uncertainty that makes me hold back my thoughts, because I fear I'm wrong or that speaking up will change everything. It's incredibly frustrating to have something right there in my face, but yet I'm not looking at it.

My sleep is often disrupted; I end up falling asleep but then wake up late, and the quality isn't great. Beyond that, I don't have transportation, which limits my ability to get around.

I've been diagnosed with PTSD a few weeks ago by a psychiatrist, and that's part of what's going on. I'm trying to cope with everything. I meditate, which has really been helping, and I also vent, turn things into jokes, or write. I also enjoy yoga and riding my bike when I can. Therapy has been highly useful for me; it helps me understand myself and my issues better. I'm also trying to be more assertive with my doctors, because the medication I'm on right now is really messing with my mood, and I believe I should be on something different. It's frustrating when doctors don't seem to listen.

There was one night, not long ago, when I felt truly happy – I stayed up without my meds, danced, and climbed trees. It was a good 24 hours, but that's not my typical state. I'm still adjusting to civilian life after the military, and all these feelings are a part of that ongoing process.

summary:
I'm Marina, and I've been diagnosed with depression for over ten years now. It's a significant part of my life. My mood can fluctuate quite a bit; sometimes I feel happy, but often I'm just depressed. There are a lot of different things that can trigger my depression, and some days are good, while others are bad. I prefer not to go into detail about what triggers me, as it's not something I care to talk about.

This depression impacts my daily life, especially my sleep. Some nights I can sleep fine, but on other nights, I have to medicate myself just to get some rest. I find myself restless and irritable, and I can be quite cranky when I'm trying to go to sleep. Overall, life feels like a daily struggle, and honestly, I'm just tired of being tired.

When it comes to coping, I sometimes use medication to manage my depression. Other times, I just try to pick myself up, move on, and do what needs to be done. I believe you have to get up, confront these struggles, and keep moving forward. I also listen to jazz to relax, and I enjoy going to the movies.

I've been in therapy for a long time, and while it helps sometimes to get a better perspective on my situation, it's not always useful. Sometimes I'm open to listening and giving input, but other times I just close myself off from everything. It's hard to say what changes I've noticed, as I've been doing it for so long.

Feeling truly happy has been a while. I can't think of anything specific that has made me exceptionally happy recently. My family, my wife and kids, are positive influences, but our relationship can be on-again, off-again, like the normal rigors of any American family. Some days we're dysfunctional, and other days everything clicks. I consider myself a shy person, and I'm not even sure how my best friends find me. Overall, it's a constant effort to navigate my days with this depression. It's a struggle, but I keep trying to move forward.

summary:
I've been dealing with depression for a long time now, over ten years since I was diagnosed. My feelings fluctuate; sometimes I'm happy, but other times I'm definitely depressed. It's just a general state of being depressed. I can't really think of anything that's made me exceptionally happy lately; it's been a while since I felt that way. I'm tired of being tired.

This impacts my daily life quite a bit. Getting a good night's sleep is often a challenge; some nights are fine, but others I have to medicate myself because I'm restless and irritable. I can be pretty cranky when I'm trying to sleep. Overall, life feels like a daily struggle. I have to get up, confront things, and just move on. My relationships with my family, my wife and kids, are on again, off again, like a normal family, but sometimes we're dysfunctional, and other times everything clicks.

In terms of symptoms, beyond the pervasive depressed mood, I experience restlessness and irritability, especially around sleep. I also find myself closing off from things, even in therapy.

A lot of different things can trigger my depression, and some days are good while others are bad. I don't really care to talk about what triggers it. To cope, sometimes I rely on medication, especially for sleep. Other times, I just try to pick myself up and move on, doing what needs to be done. I've been in therapy for a long time, and it helps sometimes, giving me a better perspective on my situation. But sometimes I'm open to listening or giving input, and other times I just close myself off from everything. For relaxation, I like listening to jazz, and I enjoy going to the movies.
